Title: Find Themselves
Description Engilish: Visitors are invited to "find themselves" in a grain of rice: as soon as they enter the exhibition, the grain of rice is given to them, creating a unit of connection between the visitor and the basic vision, allowing the user to feel part of it.

Title: Slumber
Description Engilish: Between 1994 and 2000, the artist slept while a polysomnography machine recorded her eye movements. During the day, Anthony would sit at the loom and weave pieces of pajamas following her REM patterns. These patterns were woven into the blankets that covered the bed where the artist slept at night.

Title: Be the Data
Description Engilish:
Each student embodied a data point, and the student's position in physical space represented a two-dimensional projection of the high-dimensional data. Students move around the room with each other, co-constructing alternative projections and receiving visual feedback on the relevant data dimensions. In this way, students can formulate hypotheses about the data to discover statistical support and learn complex concepts such as high-dimensional distances.

Translated with DeepL.com (free version)

Title: #Good vs. #Evil
Description Engilish: There is a race going on between two Twitter hashtags consisting of two cars. The blue car represents #good and the red car represents #evil.

Title: The mood test
Description Engilish: A wall in the public square was initially blank, showing only a timeline and inviting passers-by to interact with it. Participants drew a circle with coloured chalk and let it represent their mood at that time. By placing the centre of the circle on the timeline, setting the radius according to the participant's age (or other income information) and choosing a colour more suited to their mood, the experience is created, culminating in a vivid wall

Title: Durrell Bishop's Marble Answering Machine
Description Engilish: Considered one of the earliest tangible user interfaces (TUIs). For each voice message recorded, the answering machine spits out a marble. The order of the marbles indicates the order in which the messages arrived. The message could be played back by placing the marble in a small notch. If the message is for someone else, it can be placed in a small dish on the side, which can be labelled with different people's names. The telephone itself also has a small recess for the marbles, and by placing the message there, the original caller will be listened to back.

Title: 100% City
Description Engilish: A representative sample of 100 people from a specific city was selected and then invited to perform on stage. Each person briefly introduces themselves and then each participates in a series of physical visualisation performances, each playing the role of a data point.

Title: Dust Serenade: Sound Waves Materializedht
Description Engilish: Visualisation of longitudinal sound waves through dust: tubes filled with fragments of words and letters - the theory of the clipped - interact with sound waves and take the shape of dust. Here, visitors can regulate the frequency of the sound emitted by moving a rod to produce different harmonic effects. As the sound waves shape, reshape and destroy the text, visitors are invited to rethink the tension between theoretical knowledge and sensory experience.

Title: Solar Radiation Dowsing Rod
Description Engilish: The Solar Radiation Sensor Rod is a device designed for the Space Observatory that allows visitors to point it towards the sky and feel the level of radiation from that direction through light, vibration and sound. It is only during the interaction that one can perceive data through this rod (as the data is not encoded in the shape of the artefact, but is experienced through it).

Title: x.pose: a Wearable Dynamic Data Sculpture
Description Engilish: Create a mobile application and server to automate data collection over time. Use the recorded data set as the basis for the generation of personalised wearable fashion. Control a reactive display to change opacity to show the wearer's skin.

Title: Drip-By-Tweet: Each Vote is Drop
Description Engilish: A real-time physical visualisation voting system. People can vote for a specific work by sending a tweet, after which the machine releases a drop of yellow liquid and delivers it into the appropriate test tube.

Title: Wage Islands
Description Engilish: Submerge a topographical map of New York City to visualise where low-wage workers can afford to rent. There is a button on the front of the installation, and pressing and holding the button increases the wages shown on the display. As the wage increases, the map emerges from the water, showing more and more of New York City.

Title: Yellow Dust: Making Visible Particulate Matter in the Air
Description Engilish: A three-dimensional water vapour canopy; it is a perceptual and sensory infrastructure that monitors, displays and partially remediates airborne particulate matter through variable clouds of yellow mist. The quality of air pollution is communicated not through screens or numbers, but through the sensory experience of the data; as well as the conditioning of the environment through humidification and cooling.

Title: The Long Run: Marble Runs Convey Cost of Health Care
Description Engilish: A work of art that represents the cost of healthcare at different ages based on the time it takes for the marbles to fall.Each of the seven runs represents a different decade of life, and the length of the run represents the average cost of care at the NHS in that year. Each run was constructed from medical equipment.

Title: Econundrum: Visualizing the Climate Impact of Dietary Choices
Description Engilish: Econundrum is a shared physical system designed to visualise the carbon emissions resulting from dietary choices. People in the community can show on their mobile phones which foods they have eaten that day and this information will be visualised on the physical device. Each disc represents a person's impact and its height indicates the level of impact: the higher it is the less carbon emissions, the lower it is the more carbon emissions. The highlighted food groups visualise how each person's 'food footprint' is made up. Circles of different sizes in the disc indicate the impact ratio of different food types and can be used to select alternatives to reduce carbon emissions.

Title: LOOP: Ambient Visualization of Personal Activity
Description Engilish: It consists of eight rings, seven of which represent workdays from small to large, with the outermost ring representing the step goal. When the owner is active, the ring representing the current workday moves up and corresponds to the step goal ring.LOOP was used to investigate how an alternative method of representing personal activity data could support self-tracking activities in everyday life.

Title: Pulse Room: Light Bulbs Show Heart Beats
Description Engilish: It consists of one to three hundred transparent incandescent light bulbs, evenly distributed throughout the exhibition room. On one side of the exhibit room is an interface with a sensor that detects the heart rate of the participant. When someone holds the interface, the computer detects his or her pulse and immediately activates the bulb closest to him or her to blink in the exact rhythm of the heartbeat. The moment the interface is released, all the lights go out briefly and the blinking sequence advances one position along the queue to the next bulb in the grid. Each time someone touches the interface, a heartbeat pattern is recorded and sent to the first bulb in the grid, thus advancing all existing records. At any given time, the device displays the most recent participant's record.

Title: Pan-Anthem: Visualize Statistics Using National Anthems
Description Engilish: An interactive sound installation that plays the national anthems of the countries of the world through movable speakers magnetically attached to a large wall. The precise arrangement of the speakers allows for the visualisation of national statistics: population, GDP, area, number of women in parliament, GINI, year of independence, Human Development Index, etc. For example, when the work is configured to show military spending per capita, on the far left of the wall the public can hear the national anthems of Costa Rica, Iceland, and Andorra, countries with no army, while on the far right they can hear the national anthems of Saudi Arabia, Israel, and the United States, whose per capita military spending exceeds $2,000 per year. If there is no one in the gallery, all the speakers are muted, but when a visitor approaches a specific set of speakers, they play automatically, creating a panoramic playback of the location of national anthems associated with similar statistics.

Title: Pulse Drip
Description Engilish: The public can water the lawn of Torre de Madariaga using a hose with a built-in heart rate sensor. To take part, visitors can bring the hose wherever they want to water: by placing their index finger on the micro-sensor on the nozzle, his or her pulse is detected and an automatic electromechanical valve controls the water flow to match the participant's heartbeat.

Title: In-Formed: More Data-Driven Tableware
Description Engilish: Data-driven cutlery, this time delivering world statistics. The forks pictured show calorie consumption in the United States and three other countries.

Title: Keyboard Frequency Sculpture
Description Engilish: A three-dimensional bar graph at the top of the keyboard shows the frequency of occurrence of each letter in the alphabet.

Title: Dan Gilbert's TV Ads
Description Engilish: The Ribbon Experiment: Have bystanders estimate how much money they will need when they retire. Then, give each person a ribbon and have them cut the ribbon based on how long that money will actually be used. The ribbons are then assembled into a large radial visualisation.

Title: Dan Gilbert's TV Ads
Description Engilish: Age stickers: ask people how old the oldest person they know is and then give them each a sticker to put on the wall to construct a histogram.

Title: Dan Gilbert's TV Ads
Description Engilish: MAGNET EXPERIMENT: Dan asked people to remember things that happened in the past and things that might happen in the future. Good things were put on yellow magnets and bad things on blue magnets. The results of the resulting participatory visualisation clearly show that people tend to be overly optimistic about their future.

Title: Walkable Bar Chart
Description Engilish: A bar graph expressing two quantities, one of which is significantly larger. Yesterday, activists and artists participating in the Respect New Haven rally provided this stunning chart visualising Yale's $32 billion endowment in relation to its paltry $13 million contribution to the City of New Haven ...... If properly assessed, this is only a fraction of the taxes Yale would be liable to pay.

Title: Garden of Eden
Description Engilish: Eden" consists of eight lettuces, each in its own airtight Plexiglas box, representing a major city. The ozone concentration in each box is controlled in real time to reflect the city's current pollution levels.

Title: Gibson's Pharmacy clay interactive exhibition
Description Engilish: Located within the Science Museum's impressive medical galleries, Gibson's Pharmacy is housed in a partially reconstructed historic pharmacy, providing an immersive digital experience. The pharmacy was originally founded in Hexham in 1834 and was acquired by the Science Museum after the shop closed in 1978.

Title: Virtuali-Tee
Description Engilish: AR t-shirt that maps directly to the body

Title: Month-of-Rebounds-Day-13-AR-Watch
Description Engilish: Wearable AR watch that records body temperature, heart rate, and more!

Title: Dear-Data
Description Engilish: Dear Data is a year-long analogue data mapping project by Giorgia Lupi and Stefanie Posavec, two award-winning information designers living on both sides of the Atlantic. They became friends by collecting and hand-drawing their personal data and sending it to each other in the form of postcards.

Title: medium.com/data-physicaliz
Description Engilish:
We found that the process of preparing fabrics using the kumo technique matched our dataset very well; we felt that there was an intuitive link between the expression of stress and the act of collecting fabrics to form a series of knots. In our early experiments with kumo, we found the process of preparing fabric to be almost ritualised. It requires patience and attention and therefore can be used as a therapeutic behaviour. Thus, we saw an opportunity to use the preparation process (collecting small areas and tying them with rubber bands) as a direct input to the final representation. (This means that the final output is not a symbolic representation pattern imposed on the dataset, but appears organically as an indexed representation of the data.) Thus, creating these knots can help alleviate the pressure they are meant to embody.

"Stress Blanket."
Finally, we chose to create a personalised blanket using Shibori dyed fabrics. We saw this as an opportunity to once again combine data with physical representation and chose to create an object that would provide comfort during times of stress.

Title: Sheldon.studio - Cancer data expierience
Description Engilish:
"Between 30 and 50 per cent of cancer cases are preventable. Prevention offers the most cost-effective long-term strategy for controlling cancer" (World Health Organisation).

Currently, in Italy, awareness of cancer spread and prevention is rather low, despite the existence of many educational websites, printed materials and online campaigns. On average, cancer is still considered as a fatal disease, which can affect information processing. Information avoidance is indeed a typical behaviour, especially when it comes to cancer-related issues.

At TedMed Milan 2017, organised by the Politecnico di Milano in Italy, KnowAndBe.live, a startup dedicated to cancer prevention awareness, asked us to design an information-rich experience that would be able to communicate to the audience about cancer prevention in a new way. Such a delicate topic. The main requirements were to raise awareness of best practices in cancer prevention, avoid traditional top-down healthcare communication, and potentially gather information about participants' knowledge at the same time. After several workshops and conferences featuring a co-design approach, we defined a participatory data physicalisation that aims to go beyond the boundaries of normal data physicalisation and transform it into a participatory experience.
What are we talking about? We are referring to the emerging field of data visualisation, known as physicalisation, consisting of physical objects that represent data and then create information. Data becomes tangible and experienceable through shapes and materials, driving information through a new (physical) paradigm. But what happens when the physicalisation of data becomes a participatory experience where people actively contribute to the shared experience with their actions? Dell's cone of experience gives us a hint of what might happen.

Title: Form-follows-data
Description Engilish:
Indirectly, the location of materials is related to the landscape and its historical and cultural context. For example, the Christmas marble used to carve the Lincoln Memorial comes from the Christmas Creek Valley in the mountains of Colorado. In geology, marble is metamorphic limestone, and historically, marble has been widely used in architecture and figurative sculpture. (In fact, stone sculpture is one of the earliest forms of art, predating paintings on cave walls.) Culturally, marble has become a symbol of tradition and refined taste.

In my artwork series entitled "Arctic Sea Ice/Albedo", I converted photographic data of Arctic sea ice patterns into a digitally modelled surface. The template was cut using a CNC milling machine and a glass casting kiln. The concept of the data is physically represented through the translucent material of the glass. Depth is conveyed in graduated blue tones and the glass even captures tiny air bubbles!

Title: the-rhythm-of-violence
Description Engilish:
We set out to create an impactful installation that would make tangible this invisible, systemic violence against women around the world
A universal language was created through the use of metronomes, sounds and rhythms to communicate the consistency and global nature of this threat, despite the media attention that may be focused on these dangers

Title: conversations-on-suicide
Description Engilish: Dialogue can save lives. In Catalonia, 62 people try to end their lives every week, and suicide is considered the number one cause of death among young people. But we often find that social taboos leave people struggling with their feelings, and mental health professionals, as well as those who have attempted suicide, agree that simply talking about it is the best way to prevent it.

Title: about-time
Description Engilish:
Paper Clock
Throughout history, we humans have tried to encapsulate time, control time, and manage time, and we have created millions of artefacts to do so. It's easy to say that time is the number we read off a clock, but we know it's much more complex than that. We are particularly interested in exploring how such a familiar concept can be so elusive and difficult to define.
In making this installation, with the help of our partners in crime at Hamill Industries, we combined two key elements: play and materiality.
Firstly, we know from experience that through play and interaction we can create a more honest and emotional connection with visitors. Secondly, when considering materiality, we were keen to use ink and paper similar to those used in traditional Chinese crafts. In the course of our research, we came across the typical folded paper fan, which in a way reminded us of the shape of a clock.

Title: data-heartbreak
Description Engilish:
The data on information consumption and generation comes as no surprise: while 6,000 new tweets, 740,741 WhatsApp messages are sent and 694 Instagram posts are made every second, new reports tell us that the duration of the human attention span is getting shorter every year (currently 8 seconds) ).
We have more information than ever before, and it's growing at an unprecedented rate, while we're losing the ability to focus, pay attention and analyse. This is a source of anxiety, which translates into apathy and inaction.

Title: lifeline
Description Engilish: We created a space where people could experience data on a very important subject in an extended physical way. The installation consisted of a grid of 800 balloons marking the point between a person's actual age and the age they wish to die, and comparing the information to their gender. The higher the balloon, the more the public responded to that point. White balloons represent spaces where no one wants to die.

Title: the-great-imagination
Description Engilish:
In this context, domestic data streaming media were involved in the production of two works that contributed to the global narrative of the exhibition.
"Accelerate" welcomes you to the exhibition. An immersive sculpture that tells us about the growing interest in the concept of "the future". The article is based on data from Google Trends, which shows the number of articles and news items published on the platform from 2008 to the present day that include the word "future". A three-dimensional exercise in data visualisation, materialised in light, sound and experience.

Title: sand-falls
Description Engilish: We created five sand clocks (one for each artwork to be analysed) and connected each one to a different audience-tracking device that transferred visitors' interest to the sand grains in real time. With one of the oldest mechanical instruments, we created a new kind of time reading that could quantify the impact of each group over the course of a month.

Title: the-time-machine
Description Engilish: To this end, we have created a time machine; an experience that will enable leading politicians to go back to their childhood and connect with it through music. The Time Machine was designed to bring meaning to the lack of data on these serious issues, while explaining the importance of access to information for policy development. The device was used by 246 prominent UN politicians and influenced the agenda of the UN General Assembly the following year; there was an unprecedented increase in the use of the term 'information gap'. To this end, we created a time machine; an experience that will enable leading politicians to return to their childhood and connect with it through music. The time machine aims to bring meaning to the lack of data on these serious issues, while explaining the importance of access to information for policy development. The device was used by 246 prominent United Nations politicians and influenced the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly the following year; there was an unprecedented increase in the use of the term "information gap".

Title: e-senior
Description Engilish: A street intervention on how to do better for the older generation and ensure they remain independent We rebuilt a whole set of flats on one of the main avenues in Hospitalet, a suburb of Barcelona, to inspire passers-by to talk about and think about how to support older members of the community who may be living alone.

Title: la-gata-perduda
Description Engilish: The opera tells the story of the mysterious disappearance of the landmark statue "EIGato de Botero", usually found on the main street of Raval, and the resulting recovery of the statue, with every part of the neighbourhood gathered under the stage lights. We worked with Tucker to develop an interactive installation in the Sal dels miralls of the iconic Riccio Theatre, telling the story of the 1,428 days that brought one of Barcelona's most historic neighbourhoods to the Opera House.

Title: eat-act-impact
Description Engilish:
How do our food choices change the world we live in?
Perhaps the Collective Impact Calculator can help us answer such a complex question The installation, a circular room of mirrors, is a data-responsive piece that changes according to the number of people in the exhibition. Using counterest technology, the room is able to modify its content to provide customised information that communicates directly to the visitor:What would be the impact if everyone in the room didn't eat meat for a year? How much CO2 emissions could be reduced if they all shopped locally? How much waste could be avoided if they started recycling tomorrow? The Collective Impact Calculator is a vivid data experience that demonstrates how joint action can be linked to real change.

Title: the-city-lab
Description Engilish: The City Lab used different lab equipment to ask the audience a series of questions and collect the answers in liquid form. Topics included emotions such as love, fear, worry, ambition and purpose to help participants construct a bigger picture of Jerusalem. We wanted everyone to create a formula based on their own view of the city. There is also a layer of sound; whenever a participant chooses an answer, the installation produces a certain sound that becomes part of the collective song.

Title: the-world-pulse
Description Engilish: All the data collected is then translated into one heartbeat for each goal; the screen visualises every social media mention around the issue and will create a new peak in its lifeline, while the touchable sphere representing the Earth will vibrate. In this way, it is possible to see how active each goal is and how much impact these 17 SDGs are having on the world. World Pulse is an installation that brings together data, emotion and knowledge

Title: scents-of-the-city-first-smell-based-travel-agent
Description Engilish: The campaign continues from 2015's Sounds of the City, in which Rosapark installed playable billboards where passers-by could plug into a headphone jack and hear recorded sounds from across Europe (case study film below). Following on from Sounds and Smells of the City, we can't wait to see what the agency comes up with next: the Sights, Sensations and Tastes of the City and, apparently, maybe even The Sixth Sense of the City, in which (spoiler alert) the most famous twisted tale of all time) Bruce Willis dies in 14 European cities.

Title: 4-international-office-spaces
Description Engilish:
To give American consumers a better look at the VR headsets and mobile devices made by Samsung Electronics, the South Korean company decided to set aside 28,000 square feet of space in its New York office for innovation demonstrations. Then we got a call from a designer who typically works in fashion environments: Wonderwall's talented chief Masamichi Katayama, who has handled interiors for clients ranging from streetwear brand A Bathing Ape to mass-market brand Uniqlo, has set the pace of the retail industry with his Tokyo design. Tokyo Design.

For US-based Samsung, the result is a stunning project complete with a VR tunnel, a three-storey video wall, a recording studio, and Douglas fir and oak accents that pay homage to a nature that's not usually present in the tech world. The combination is neither a showroom nor a shop - there's nothing like it. "This space belongs to visitors. It should be their place in the city," says Katayama. He even made sure passersby could see enough through the storefront to get their own brief brand experience.

Title: seed-cathedral-heatherwick-studio
Description Engilish:
The Cathedral of Seeds for the UK Pavilion at the Shanghai World Expo 2010 was designed by Heatherwick Studio: a fascinating fusion of design, nature and technology that urges us to embrace a harmonious balance between the city and the environment.
Heatherwick Studio's ingenious creation, the Cathedral of Seeds, embodies the spirit of the Expo's theme, Better City, Better Life, and takes it to new heights of artistic expression. As one of the most anticipated attractions at the Expo, the pavilion demonstrates an innovative approach to architecture that focuses on the harmonious relationship between the urban environment and the natural world.

The centrepiece of the UK Pavilion is the Cathedral of Seeds, a 20-metre high structure made up of 60,000 transparent fibre optic rods, each containing a seed at its tip. These dazzlingly illuminated seeds, sourced from the Royal Botanic Gardens' Millennium Seed Bank and the Kunming Institute of Botany in China, form a celestial constellation of plant diversity. The Cathedral's ethereal glow and gentle movement with the wind creates a dynamic, immersive experience for visitors, promoting introspection and reverence for the world's plant species.

Title: plankton-populations
Description Engilish:
This interactive display shows microscopic sea creatures called phytoplankton. Visitors use special lenses to see what the phytoplankton look like and find out what different parts of the ocean they live in at different times of the year.

"We used scientific models created by MIT," said Associate Curator Jennifer Frazier. "Because the exhibit is based on real data, if you were able to look at the ocean with a microscope, this is what you might see. I'm excited about this exhibit because it continues the Discovery Museum's tradition of giving people insights into amazing phenomena in the natural world, but with the help of new scientific data, visitors can explore the world on a scale they wouldn't normally see."

Title: salt-worldwide
Description Engilish:
The German Salt Museum in Lüneburg has updated its exhibition with an interactive installation called "Salt World". This media installation concludes the tour of the museum (former salt mine).

34 touch-sensitive salt crystals are distributed on a world map highlighting the largest salt mines. Depending on the amount of salt mined in these areas, millions of grains of salt are discharged onto the world map, sliding down the ridges and then spreading and flowing with the major sea currents.

When the crystal is touched, it begins to glow. The salt grains are poured onto a table and merge into an information window which displays detailed information about the selected salt mine in the form of text, images and film.

During the guided tour, the museum guide explains in a ten-minute sequence the global production, consumption, use of salt and other related topics. Each topic is illustrated through computationally generated animations.

The installation offers a new approach to learning through a dynamic and immersive experience. The behaviour of the salt world is based on algorithmic parameters, providing a vivid and ever-changing experience over time.

Title: ink-bleed-calendar
Description Engilish: This is a crazy calendar! Dip the paper well into the ink, change one colour each month, and watch the bleeding charts for the past few days.

Title: the-art-of-clean-up
Description Engilish: This project by Swiss artist Ursus Wehrli and his book "The Art of Cleaning Up" is a brilliant concept for organising everything around us in our daily lives. Objects are methodically aligned and arranged according to their colour, size or shape.

Title: Data-Things
Description Engilish: Data from conference twitter conversations and craft practitioner actions were transformed into interactively generated and manufactured physical artefacts respectively. We argue that direct participation in such digital fabrication activities can help people invest meaning in artefacts, facilitating social interaction and reflection on their activities, while encouraging practitioners to incorporate new forms into their own work. On this basis, we reconsider digital fabrication in the context of data translation activities as an extended 'trajectory of use' in which reflective 'data artefacts' can be created.

Title: Physikit
Description Engilish: Physikit, a system designed to allow users to explore and use environmental data through the visualisation of the physical environment.

Title: Fantibles
Description Engilish: Sports fans are increasingly using social media platforms such as Twitter to express emotions and share opinions while watching sports programmes on television. These comments describe the intensely subjective experience fans have while watching sports. We saw an opportunity to capture these nostalgic moments in physical form. We launched 'Fantibles', personalised sports memorabilia that highlights individuals' comments on Twitter about sport and the uniqueness of each sporting event.

Title: Chemicals in the Creek
Description Engilish: Create a community-based data display using U.S. Environmental Protection Agency data on water permit violations at the Chelsea Creek Oil Storage Facility in Massachusetts to explore whether situational data physicalisation and participatory action research can support meaningful engagement with open data.

Title: Documented
Description Engilish: Implemented and evaluated Documented, a web application that helps producers associate documents with 3D printed objects. Information can be embedded in the model via printed labels and accessed via mobile AR. Our study highlights the different strategies participants use to organise, embed and retrieve information.

Title: ListeningCups
Description Engilish: A set of 3D printed porcelain mugs embedded with a dataset of everyday environmental sounds. In a week-long pilot project, a ceramic artist and an interaction design researcher collaborated to explore the generation of meaning from everyday data (in our case, sound). We developed a workflow for capturing the data, preparing the dataset, transcribing the data from decibels to G-code, and producing a set of 3D printed porcelain cups that represent this data in textural and tactile form.

Title: Population Theatre
Description Engilish: "Population Theatre is a scalable data visualisation theatre consisting of 7.5 billion individual computer-controlled points of light. The purpose of the work is to create an experience that provides a one-to-one relationship between the world's population and its data: each living person is represented by a point of light. "The Population Theatre is a material representation of human existence, and as such it can be used to create "data dramatisations" that help visitors visualise areas of political economy, cultural studies, sociology, anthropology, psychology, history, communications and more. Data can be presented using a content management system with automated or interactive playlists of 10-minute vignettes created by different data performers. People can stand on the stage to watch the presentation, but they are also encouraged to walk along the corridor between the 'rows' of monitors, physically 'zooming in' to see individual perxons, reversing the panoramic view and reviewing the public stage. Each monitor produces subtle feedback sounds as the data changes, and walking along the corridor creates a spatialised sound experience.

Title: Wheeled Micro-Robots
Description Engilish: Wheeled robots self-propelled collections of objects to represent data, giving examples of how the committee could view resumes by treating these little robots as students

Title: EdiPulse
Description Engilish: Self-monitoring is good for raising awareness of physical activity, but this data-centred activity is not always an enjoyable experience. We present EdiPulse, a novel system for creating active snacks that provide a fun reflection on daily physical activity through the appealing medium of chocolate, which translates self-monitored physical activity data into small, 3D-printed chocolate snacks. These small treats (less than 20 grams of total chocolate weight) take four forms: graphics, flowers, slogans and emoticons.

Title: Skintillates
Description Engilish: Skintillates is a wearable technology that mimics tattoos - the oldest and most commonly used skin display device in human culture. We demonstrate that a wide variety of displays and sensors can be made by creating electrical traces and thin electronic components on temporary tattoo paper. Like traditional temporary tattoos often worn by children and adults, Skintillates bend naturally with the user's skin. Our simple fabrication techniques also give users the freedom to design and print in a variety of colours to create custom designs for specific applications. Through a series of application examples, we demonstrate the technical capabilities of Skintillates as sensors and as expressive personal and private displays. Finally, we detail the results of a series of user studies that highlight the user experience, comfort, durability, acceptability and application potential of Skintillates.

Title: Tensions of Data-Driven Reflection
Description Engilish: Biosensing displays are increasingly used for emotional reflection, promising to provide authoritative insights by compartmentalising the user's emotions. With the Emotional Biosensing Display we sought to explore an alternative approach to having emotions interpreted by machines, in which users can form their own interpretations and feel comfortable criticising the display. We therefore designed, implemented and deployed the Emotional Biosensing Display as a technological inquiry: the Ripple is a shirt whose pattern changes colour in response to the wearer's skin conductivity, which has been linked to arousal.17 Participants wore the Ripple over two days of daily life.While some participants expressed appreciation for the " physical connection," for others, the Ripple created insecurity about "how much" they felt emotionally. Despite our design intent, we found that participants rarely questioned the relationship between the display and their emotions. We utilised biopolitics to speculate on Ripple's surprising authority, highlighting the ethical stakes that biosensory representations have on self-awareness and ways of feeling.

Title: PiHearts
Description Engilish:
A person's heartbeat can be sensed and displayed by sensors for others to see, hear, feel, and potentially "empathise" with. Previous interaction design work examining physiological data such as heart pulse has argued that feeding this data back to the user can help them become more mindful and self-aware in a variety of daily activities, ultimately promoting their physical and mental health. Inspired by the discipline of somatosensory aesthetics, we have designed and explored multimodal displays that enable people to experience heartbeats as natural stimuli from themselves and others in their social neighbourhood. In this paper, we report on the design process for our design, PiHearts, and present qualitative findings from a field study with 30 pairs of participants.
Participants were asked to use PiHearts while watching a short film together and to report on their perceptual experiences in three different display conditions while watching the film. For example, we found that participants experienced a significant effect on sensory immersion when they received their own heartbeat as a stimulus compared to a condition without any heartbeat display, and that feeling their partner's heartbeat had a significant effect on the social experience. We invoke resonance theory to explain and discuss these results, highlighting the potential resonance of digitising heartbeats as rhythmic natural stimuli in a modern society facing accelerated social development.

Title: Corsican Twin
Description Engilish: We present Corsican Twin, a tool for producing augmented reality data visualisations in virtual reality using digital twins. The system provides users with the necessary contextual information to design embedded and situated data visualisations in a secure and convenient remote environment. We created the system through a co-design process involving people with little to no programming experience. Using the system, we illustrate three potential use cases for scenario-based visualisation in the context of building maintenance, including (1) on-site equipment commissioning and diagnostics, (2) remote incident playback, and (3) operational simulation of future buildings. Through feedback gathered during the formative evaluation of our prototype tool with domain experts, we discuss the implications, opportunities, and challenges for future scenario visualisation design tools.

Title: Informing the design of situated glyphs for a care facility
Description Engilish: This paper first introduces 'situational glyphs' - a graphic entity used to encode situationally specific information - and then presents the results of our on-site qualitative research into the information space of such glyphs. The study aimed to reveal the information space associated with primary and secondary healthcare through technical probing using situational glyphs and different glyph display form factors. The analyses resulted in a large number of information types and a deeper understanding of the design principles for future situational glyphs. We report our findings in this paper, which we hope will provide a solid foundation for designing future assistive systems to support patient care activities.

Title: Cairn
Description Engilish:
In this catalogue, we present the design process and functionality of Cairn, a tangible device that enables data collection and visualisation, designed within a FabLab community of practice in France:
A tangible device that enables data collection, visualisation and analysis, Cairn was designed within a FabLab community of practice in France to understand the various practices within FabLab.Cairn explores tangible alternatives to questionnaires and other traditional assessment techniques and emphasises the aesthetic and emotional dimensions to create an engaging experience. It invites Fablab visitors to reflect on their practice by materialising their activities using small coloured wooden bricks. Through individual interactions with Cairn, a collaborative and meaningful sculpture was co-created on which to collectively reflect. We will discuss the opportunities the prototype presents for future research in situated human-computer interaction.

Title: Inverted Participatory Bar Charts
Description Engilish:
Participatory physical visualisation where people vote by picking badges from a tank.
The lower the badge, the more votes.

Title: Psychogeographical Mapping
Description Engilish: American artist Cory Imig has reconstructed the layout of the city of Savannah using Lego blocks, adding a coloured block to each specific place she visits over the course of a month. Each colour represents a different day of the week.

Title: How Much Sugar do you Consume?
Description Engilish:
Nutrition labelling is often difficult to understand: when you drink a can of Coke, you consume 39 grams of sugar, but how much is that really?
To raise consumers' awareness of sugar intake in their diets, some campaigns have used physical visualisations, using actual cubes and grains of sugar to represent the amount of sugar in food.

Title: Federal Budget Explained with 10,000 Pennies
Description Engilish:
Political Math (Youtube channel formerly known as "10,000 Pennies") is a blogger who uses statistics and low-tech physical visualisations to criticise US policy.
His first video in 2009, titled "Obama Budget Cuts Visualisation" (pictured left), received 1.7 million views. Coins, notes, water or whiskey all represent money or work units. The video usually ends with a dramatic action where the blogger splits a penny in half, knocks over a gallon container, spills hundreds of coins from a table, freezes water, or drinks a glass of whiskey.

Title: LIVING MAP
Description Engilish:
To visualise the LIVING MAP data, we designed a local ecosystem.
A living fire moss (Ceratondon purpureus) was plated on a special surface. This moss visualises the presence or absence of water. If the moss gets enough water, it turns green. If it lacks water, it turns brown or yellow. Too much moisture will turn the moss black. The amount of water in the moss map is controlled. The amount of water is related to numerical data. Different areas of the map have different amounts of water. After a few months, a special pattern of moss forms on the surface of the map. It is a metaphor for the possible environmental conditions on the European continent in 2070.

The Living Map is an experimental visualisation project linked to a PhD research at the Vilnius Academy of Arts in Lithuania. It explores ways of presenting "rich information experiences".

Title: Traveling Datavis Game
Description Engilish:
Public engagement project on the boundaries of political debate.
The project aspires to define a respectable "clean" political discourse and to create a treaty reflecting the public's expectations of what constitutes legitimate discourse based on political ideology, or clarifying what constitutes an abuse of a public position.
The project consisted of an ice cream truck that travelled around Israel, inviting the public to participate in 4 interactive games, asking questions about dilemmas in political discourse.

Title: Wearable Self
Description Engilish:
Wearable Self is a collection of data jewellery that was Jiyeon Kang's master's thesis project at Parsons School of Design.
Korean designer Jiyeon Kang transforms a year's worth of self-tracking data (e.g. daily steps) collected by Fitbit and iPhone Health into personalised fashion items that can be held and worn. Through laser cutting and 3d printing of different materials, the designer creates customisable fashion items generated from users' self data, aiming to make self-tracking data more meaningful to individuals using wearable devices. The combination of fashion design and data visualisation has allowed Wearable Self to create a unique business opportunity in the personalised fashion space, allowing users to interact with their own data while opening up a new dialogue related to data ownership and self-identity.

Title: Are you Sure you Want to Smoke?
Description Engilish:
Giacomo Flaim is a student of Communication Design at Politecnico di Milano.
He created a single-data physical visualisation model using 4,234 cigarette butts to represent the average annual tobacco consumption of Italian smokers. Labels were added to the butts to indicate the reduction in life expectancy due to different levels of smoking, ranging from 10 minutes per cigarette to more than a month per year.

Title: The All Too Evident Ashtray
Description Engilish:
ATEA is an ashtray made of concrete. It records sex-disaggregated data on smoking habits and lung cancer in the United States from 1975 to 2014.
The data are coded in concentric bubbles/hemispheres where the distance to the centre shows the incidence of lung cancer for each year. The diameter of the bubble shows the average number of cigarettes smoked per day for that year.

Title: Physical Customer Satisfaction Survey
Description Engilish:
Participatory physical bar graph at the exit of the Antell cafeteria at the University of Helsinki.
White beads represent satisfied customers and red beads represent dissatisfied customers.

Title:
good
night
sms
Description Engilish:
Paul Heinicker, a master's student in Interaction Design at the University of Applied Sciences in Potsdam, has created a data-driven necklace representing a long-distance relationship using the "good night" messages he sends to his girlfriend.
While visualising two years of message history, the two diagonal opposing points of the rectangle form the starting point of those two years. In each case, the persistent sides represent days with and without goodnight text messages. Specifically, the horizontal flat side represents the number of days spent together. The vertical sides are illustrated by a line graph of the length of each of his texts. The necklace is 3D printed from high-grade steel.

Title: Touching Air: Necklace Shows Air Pollution
Description Engilish:
This necklace made by Stefanie Posavec and Miriam Quick shows a week's worth of air quality measurements in Sheffield.
Each segment is 6 hours long and its appearance reflects the concentration of particulate matter during that time. Low concentrations show a small, round, green fragment. High concentrations show a large, sharp red fragment.

Title: Pulse: Animated Heart Shows Sentiments
Description Engilish:
pulse is a real-time visualisation of recent emotional expressions in private weblog communities such as blogs.
Weblog entries are compared to a list of emotions, which references Robert Plutchik's seminal 1980 book, The Psychological Evolution of Emotions. In his book, Plutchik describes eight basic human emotions: happiness, trust, fear, surprise, sadness, disgust, anger, and anticipation. He created a diagram in which these eight emotions, along with their weakened and amplified counterparts, form a three-dimensional cone of 24 regions. The cone is the basic form of the pulse and can be amplified in 24 directions for different emotions. Whenever an emotion label or its synonym is found in a recent blog entry, the morphing object changes itself in such a way that the new volume represents a part of the overall emotional state of the current Internet surfer.

Title: and Counting…:Tattoo of War Casualties
Description Engilish:
Wafaa Bilal's brother, Haji, was killed by a missile at a checkpoint in his hometown of Kufa, Iraq, in 2004. Bilal empathises with the pain of American and Iraqi families who have lost loved ones in the war, but the deaths of Iraqis like his brother are largely unknown to the American public.

In a 24-hour live performance, Bilal turned his body into a canvas, his back tattooed with a borderless map of Iraq, with a dot near every Iraqi and American casualty city on the map - "Counting ......" (Counting......) the theme of the show. 5,000 dead American soldiers were represented by red dots (permanently visible ink) and 100,000 Iraqi casualties were represented by green ultraviolet ink dots that appeared to be invisible unless under a black light. During the performance, people from all walks of life read the names of the dead.

Title: Can We Keep Up: Sponges Show Domestic Water Usage
Description Engilish: Sponges are used to demonstrate domestic water needs in cities around the world.

Title: Stop & Frisk: Physical Data Filtering
Description Engilish:
Chilean designer Catalina Cortázar created a physical visualisation that shows the percentage of blacks, Hispanics and whites searched by the New York police in 2010.
Each of the three compartments represents a race, and the amount of powder inside is proportional to that race's population in New York. When the object is turned over, the powder falls into neighbouring compartments, and only the coarser particles cannot pass through the small holes, which represent people stopped by the police.

Title: What made me
Description Engilish:
This is an interactive public installation where visitors can select the corresponding coloured strings according to their feelings, inspirations, ideas or influences.
and connect these strings to the text on the wall to form a path that visualises the concepts associated with each feeling, inspiration, idea and influence.

Title: Data Cuisine
Description Engilish: A map showing the differences in alcohol consumption across Finland, as well as typical local food.

Title: Meshu.io: Data Jewellery you can Order Online
Description Engilish:
There's a company that lets you enter the cities you've visited and then generates physical netting that
order as necklaces, earrings or cufflinks.

Title: Cosmos: Carbon Exchange Captured in a Wooden Ball
Description Engilish: Created in a forest in the UK, this two-metre high spherical wooden sculpture represents the absorption and loss of carbon dioxide by forest trees over the course of a year.

Title: 888,246 Ceramic Poppies to Commemorate Fallen Soldiers in WW1: Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red
Description Engilish:
The Tower of London's major art installation, 'Bloodwashed Places and Red Seas', commemorates the centenary of Britain's involvement in the First World War. Created by ceramic artist Paul Cummins and set by stage designer Tom Piper, 888,246 ceramic poppies will gradually fill the Tower of London's famous moat over the summer. Each poppy represents the death of a British soldier during the war.

The poppies will surround the landmark building, not only providing a spectacular display around the Tower, but also a place for personal reflection. The scale of the poppy installation is intended to reflect the magnitude of such an important centenary event, creating a strong visual remembrance.

Title: Life in Clay: Sharing Memories through Data Pottery
Description Engilish:
A cereal bowl showing Alice and her parents Skype call logs. On the front bowl, each line represents a day of their Skype calls.
On the other bowl, each dot represents a 10-minute call. She gives one bowl to her parents as a gift and the other as a reminder to stay in touch every time they have breakfast.

Title: Participatory Representation of Happiness
Description Engilish: This 2015 materialisation is part of designer Stefan Sagmeister's exhibition on happiness. It contains a participatory representation of the happiness of the exhibition's visitors, the units that make up the representation being gumballs.

Title: Edo, a participatory data physicalization of the climate impact of dietary choices
Description Engilish:
Edo is a participatory data physicalisation designed to enable a small community to track the carbon impact of their dietary choices. Each food type has a token (disc) whose surface area indicates the carbon impact of a typical portion of that food type (data source: Agribalyse).
At the end of the meal, people can add data by selecting tokens for all the food types they have just eaten. For example, a burger with fries would require a beef token, a bun token, a salad token and a potato token. All the tokens are then added to the board, which can have different layouts. The first image shows the grouping by day, where each column shows the impact of the food consumed by the person who provided the data on that day. The second image shows the grouping by person, where each circle belongs to a person and illustrates the total carbon budget for 5 days per person if a person's goal is to stay within their budget of 2 tonnes per year.

Title: Water Map
Description Engilish:
Without water, no organic matter exists. This water installation symbolically visualises the vitality that rain brings to the whole world. Rainwater is presented and visualised as data in a very tangible way through real water droplets. The installation is characterised by a black wooden plinth with a recessed world map filled with sand.
Technically, it is realised by a micro-computer that evaluates real-time weather data and locates a water tank in an X-Y system above the world map. Where there is precipitation, drops of water fall onto the sand.

Title: Dermal Tattoo Biosensors
Description Engilish: Tattoos that change colour in response to glucose levels: Minimally invasive, injectable skin biosensors were developed to measure pH, glucose and albumin concentrations.

Title: Perpetual Plastic
Description Engilish: Using beach waste as an example, the scope of the plastics problem (in terms of the volume of production and its fate) and the changes in plastics over their life cycle were emphasised.

Title: Activity Clock
Description Engilish:
The Activity Clock is a wall clock that integrates data on the number of people who are usually present in the cafeteria of a research laboratory during the day.
This visualisation was made of paper, mounted inside a plastic wall clock and put into operation during a week's time.

Title: Public Voting Displays
Description Engilish:
Public Voting Displays is a public visualisation project on small distributed public voting displays, presenting a civic question through a data-driven narrative that has evolved into an interactive civic engagement survey display device .
In collaboration with a community council in Antwerp, the researchers distributed multiple small e-ink displays on the facades of residents' houses, showing a visualisation of air pollution levels based on PM25 sensor data, a public polling question and the results of the hosting resident, supported by infographics or text annotations, as well as the hosting resident's personal statement.

Title: Personal Data Artifact
Description Engilish:
In order to explore how materials, data, and humans collaborate to produce physical data representations, we produced a series of artefacts using collected personal data (about commuting, forgetting, and being busy) through different mediums - yarn and sound.
We exchanged these artefacts without providing guidelines on how to interpret them in order to investigate where the boundaries between maker and unreader emerge. Through the creation of handmade physicalised and sonified works, we suggest three themes for the production of personal data narratives: matching data to materials (and vice versa), the willingness to accept the co-creation of materials, and the negotiation between the experience of data and the data of experience.

Title: Bookly
Description Engilish:
We present Bookly, an interactive tool that physically represents the cumulative time of a user's reading activity through abstract volume changes.Bookly accumulates the time a user spends performing reading activities (e.g., picking up and putting down books) and provides a designated space for the book being read.
Our two-week field study with six participants showed that continuous exposure to changes in the volume representing the cumulative time spent on reading activities helped users understand their erratic reading patterns.Bookly also motivated users to improve their reading behaviour and gradually make reading part of their schedule. In addition, the clear differentiation of the book being read improves the visual affordance and accessibility of the book for users to start reading. Based on the results of the study, we confirm the possibility of materialising intangible data for self-reflection, thus facilitating changes in behaviours that are difficult to implement due to poor motivation.

Title: DayClo
Description Engilish:
We present DayClo, an interactive clock for visualising schedule data to support the user's self-reflection and self-tracking in daily life.DayClo is designed in the form of an analogue clock and time representation. It displays the user's upcoming schedule through the sequential movement of two clock hands with hidden LEDs and a display.
We deployed DayClo in the workspaces of eight participants for a period of one month to explore how the design and its interactions supported their reflections on scheduling practices. Findings showed that DayClo supported users' casual access to scheduling data and prompted them to self-track their plans. In addition, the moving clock hands showed free time in their schedules, helping to create new plans for their implicit goals. Our findings provide new opportunities for designing everyday objects as a medium for delivering and facilitating spontaneous interactions with personal data for self-reflection.

Title: GraFeet
Description Engilish:
Running is a popular physical activity with great health benefits. As runners increase their level of training, understanding their bodies becomes a key issue in achieving health through running. While runners have a plethora of body sensing opportunities, understanding complex sensor data is a challenge.
In this paper, we investigate how data from on-shoe sensors can be visualised to help runners improve their technique. We designed GraFeet - an enhanced running shoe that visualises kinematic data from a runner's foot and gait. In a user study, we compared our prototype to a standard sensor dashboard. Users found the GraFeet to work better, generate more insights, and reduce user confusion. Based on our research, we will provide findings on how data from body-worn sensors can be used to support physically active people.

Title: ADIO
Description Engilish:
Although the use of audiobooks is becoming more widespread, the audiobook experience is often perceived as "not really reading" due to its intangible and ephemeral nature. In this paper, we develop a device called ADIO that enhances the audiobook experience by presenting an individual's listening state in the form of an interactive physical bookshelf.
The ADIO displays the user's listening progress through variations in the length of the pendant and the title of the user's digital audiobook file. Our four-week field study with six participants showed that ADIO provided users with proof of listening, brought about a sense of reading, and triggered recall of audiobook content already listened to. In addition, increased audiobook visibility reminded participants to listen to audiobooks, and the physical interactions of ADIO allowed participants to develop personal patterns of audiobook listening. Our findings suggest new ways to enhance the audiobook listening experience at three stages and have further implications for the design of physical curation of users' digital archives.

Title: Motiis
Description Engilish:
The online gaming world can have a strong emotional impact on children, and parents often do not understand or even acknowledge this. However, parental understanding is crucial to the emotional development of adolescents. However, conveying emotions can be challenging, and therefore, mediums that facilitate parent-child communication can benefit. To help raise parental awareness, we have designed Motiis, a novel system that measures and visualises the emotions experienced by children during play. Haptic feedback allows the user to 'feel' the level of emotion displayed.
The system was evaluated in 17 parent-child pairs through an on-site evaluation. The results show that Motiis helps to increase parents' emotional awareness. The tangible and haptic aspects of the system help the user to engage with the data more consciously, as the tangible visualisation of the system requires active interaction with the user.Motiis enables parents to be aware of their child's emotional state in ways that are beyond the child's verbal communication skills.

Title: Laina
Description Engilish: With the growing popularity of recreational sports such as running, a number of technologies have emerged to support people in their training. However, in their current form and interaction, these technologies have adopted a fairly standardised approach, focusing on quantified data tracking through screen or audio displays. In this paper, we explore how the design space for motion feedback can be opened up by materialising dynamic data through shape-variable interfaces

Title: Exploring spatial meaning with a tangible map
Description Engilish:
In this paper, we present the Tangible Map, an interactive haptic/digital display mounted on a table designed to facilitate exploration of the environment and the data generated within it.
Translating abstract map symbols into comprehensible information can be a challenging task for visitors in urban environments, due to the level of abstraction and the disconnect between flat displays and spatial information. To address this problem, we combine a tangible user interface (created using 3D printed buildings) with dynamic spatial information.

Title: COVID-19 Deaths as Nails
Description Engilish:
An art installation at Schwäbisch Gmünd Cathedral in Germany represents the deaths of COVID-19 as nails driven into a wooden cube.
As the number of deaths increased, so did the number of nails. The text at the bottom of the steps reads "Fürchtet euch nicht", which means "Do not be afraid".

Title: Data Badges
Description Engilish:
This is a physical conference badge that attendees can make themselves by assembling tokens on a wearable canvas during the event.
During the production process, there will be an instruction sheet to help convert the tokens into various occupational characteristics.

Title: Ownership: Occlusions, Night Terrors, and Pernicious Doubt
Description Engilish:
This series of bronzes graphically illustrates gun ownership data for the United States in 2020.
Access to guns triples the risk of death by suicide. Gun owners are four times more likely to be killed in an aggressive encounter compared to non-gun owners. Women are five times more likely to be killed in domestic abuse if their partner owns a gun.

Title: Self Knitted Scarf of Train Delays
Description Engilish:
Sara Weber's mother knitted this scarf on her daily train ride to work in Munich, using different colours depending on how late the train was. Two rows per day: grey, for delays of less than 5 minutes.
Pink, for delays of 5 to 30 minutes. Red, when both trains are delayed or one is delayed for more than 30 minutes. The huge red area is during construction when trains are replaced by buses.

Title: sleep-blanket
Description Engilish: Visualisation of author Seung Lee's son's sleep patterns from birth to his first birthday. A crochet border surrounds a double knitted body. Each row represents a day. Each stitch represents 6 minutes of awake or asleep time. See also their work 2013 - Temperature Scarf and Felt Afghan Wool.

Title: Physicalizing Cardiac Blood Flow Data
Description Engilish:
Blood flow data from cardiac four-dimensional flow MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) has great potential for the study and diagnosis of flow-related diseases.
However, understanding these data is quite challenging - after all, it is a volume vector field that changes over time. In this paper, we propose a novel slice-based physical model as a complementary approach to the visualisation of blood flow data. The design of the model follows the traditional approach to viewing medical images (i.e., cross-sections), but has the added advantage of being appealingly tactile.

Title: Data jewellery shows data and potential contributing factors to national well-being
Description Engilish:
This data jewellery shows data and potential contributing factors to national well-being.
One of the earrings shows the percentage of a country's GDP in the form of stacked bars, including services, agriculture and industry. The circle at the top indicates the overall happiness ranking of a country's citizens.

Title: Spanish Dictionary Cemetery
Description Engilish:
1914-2014 includes a comparison between the official Spanish dictionaries of 1914 and 2014.
The result of the comparison is a list of all the words that are no longer included in the previous edition of the dictionary. Each word is displayed on one page to show the actual number of words missing.

Title: Phylogenetic Tree with Real Specimens
Description Engilish:
As part of his zoology course, evolutionary biologist Leo Smith has created a fish phylogenetic tree.
Each leaf is an actual fish specimen.

Title: Stretch Orchestra Marble Run
Description Engilish:
A networked sports mat made of textile sensors responds to your interactions by inviting you to experience physical activity data in a playful way;
A giant marble running track that evokes a childlike sense of wonder and fulfilment. The installation is part of a research project using materials to explore the experience of systems and technologies designed to aid behavioural change.

Title: Harassment Plants
Description Engilish:
'Harassment Plants' is a contextual materialisation exhibited in a Brazilian city, representing stories of women being harassed at a public lake.
Each vase represents a different category of harassment and contains glyphs representing cases of harassment. The colour in the middle of the vase corresponds to the type of harassment, and one of the beads has the same colour as the type of harassment. Each glyph consists of a rod, the length of which represents the time when the harassment occurred, and a pendant with multiple beads representing the victim's reaction, the age of the harasser, and so on.

Title: Landscaper: 3D Printing and Assembling of Terrain Models
Description Engilish:
Landscape models of geospatial areas provide an intuitive mechanism for exploring complex geospatial information.
However, the current methods used to create these scale models are resource-intensive, which limits their use to a few popular public places such as museums and airports.Landscaper is a system for creating these physical models using affordable 3D printers, with the aim of making the creation of these models more accessible.

Title: EuroGums: Edible Population Pyramids
Description Engilish:
Eurogum is the edible population pyramid for the 28 member states of the European Union.
In 27 countries, the eurogum is cherry-sweet, while the UK eurogum is sour due to the referendum and the UK's departure from the European Union.

Title: Coral Reefs
Description Engilish: This data sculpture, made by three design students participating in the Data Fossils 3 workshop, depicts the destruction of Australia's coral reefs (orange) and the rise in ocean temperatures (grey) since 1985.

Title: CO2 Emissions Shown with Balloons
Description Engilish:
The installation shows twenty representative countries and their CO2 emissions for 2014.
Each orange beach ball is equivalent to 100 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide. These values refer to the burning of fossil fuels and the production of cement.

Title: Green Berlin
Description Engilish: "Green Berlin" is a living map showing Berlin's parks and forests. The green areas on the wooden map are laser cut and moss grows out of the holes.

Title: Street Debaters
Description Engilish: Japanese designer Tomo Kihara invented a polling device that is both entertaining and profitable.

Title: Popsicles of Pollution
Description Engilish: Students in New Taipei City collect samples from the city's rivers, streams and harbours, which are then frozen in moulds and preserved in resin. We hope that more people will see these and change their lifestyles.

Title: Walkable Collaboration Network
Description Engilish:
Designer Dario Rodighiero has created a large (15x15m) walkable visualisation of the scientific relationship between researchers and laboratories at the ENAC Institute in EPFL, Switzerland. The visualisation is printed on a tarpaulin, a heavy covering used for trucks.
Two years ago, Dario produced a co-authorship network visualisation for the Digital Humanities 2014 conference. He initially considered displaying a large poster, but as posters were not allowed in the conference centre, he decided to create a six-metre wide carpet.

Title: Dataponics: Human-Vegetal Play
Description Engilish:
Data Aquaponics: A Game of People and Plants maps the physical activity of a person, as measured by a Fitbit, to the amount of light and water available to a potted plant.
In addition, the system measures the water in the growing hydroponic medium (in this case expanded clay) that surrounds the plant's roots and plays different internet radio stations accordingly.

Title: Thoughtforms: 3D-Printed Thoughts
Description Engilish:
Kellyann Geurts and In Dae Hwang of Monash University give physical form to thoughts by transforming EEG data into physical objects.
At three public events in Melbourne in 2016, she placed mobile EEG devices on volunteers and asked them to think about memories or emotions of their choice. Their EEG output was translated in real time into three-dimensional shapes they could see on a computer screen. Participants can then press a button to pause the shape and send it to a 3D printer. They are then invited to write descriptions of their thoughts, which are used to label the 3D object.

Title: Topographic Jewelry
Description Engilish: Jewellery produced using USGS data.

Title: WeatherWindow
Description Engilish:
Wall art that displays the weather forecast in a simple, eco-friendly and unobtrusive way. This old wooden window is a decorative piece when closed.
When open, it comes alive and is connected to the Internet. Suddenly, the 8 windows are communicating with the world, accessing weather forecasts and lighting up each window with soothing colours to convey the weather outlook.

Title: Silver Ring Shaped by DNA Profile
Description Engilish: PhD student Alireza Rezaeian has designed a silver ring whose texture and shape are uniquely determined by the wearer's DNA profile. His paper explains how mapping the data onto a physical form strikes a balance between readability and aesthetics.

Title: District 5: Tube Charts Reveal Decline in Violence
Description Engilish: California-based artist Loren Madsen, a long-time data sculptor (see our 1995 piece and interview with him), has created an outdoor sculpture with steel tubes showing the decline in eight categories of crime over 30 years. The sculpture stands in front of a police station and jail in the city of Chicago.

Title: Data Clothing: Dresses Show Air Pollution
Description Engilish:
Laura Perovich explored the concept of data-driven clothing in her master's thesis at the MIT Media Lab. The fashion pictured above shows the concentrations of 100 chemical pollutants measured in the air of a household (left). The chemicals are mapped onto small squares, and the relative concentrations are mapped onto the size of the squares. The squares repeat to form a lace pattern (the right image shows concentrations of several factory-related pollutants).

In her paper, Laura Perovich discusses how data garments could be used in the future to raise awareness of air pollution:
We can imagine that the prints on the clothes would change as the chemicals to which they are exposed change; that the shape and stiffness of the clothes would change to make them feel uncomfortable, thus encouraging people to leave heavily polluted areas; or that the clothes would provide air filtration in polluted spaces, thus improving protection. These types of projects will improve understanding by providing relevant information on an ongoing basis and prompting people to act on these realisations.

Title: Abyss Table - Scale Model of Deep Sea as Furniture
Description Engilish:
Furniture design company Duffy London designed this table as a geological profile of the ocean displayed in multiple layers of wood and glass panels.
Designer Christopher Duffy noticed during a visit to a glass factory that the colour of the glass panels darkens as the layers are added, just like the ocean.

Title: Sphere Packing: Visualize Composers' Total Musical Production
Description Engilish:
The 'Sphere Pack' is a series of 3D-printed spheres designed to bring together a composer's entire musical oeuvre in a dense, multi-channel device. For example, Johann Sebastian Bach's sphere is 48 centimetres in diameter and can accommodate 1,100 speakers playing 1,100 different Bach compositions simultaneously, while Hildegaard Von Bingen's sphere is only 11 centimetres in diameter and has only 69 speakers. The project demonstrates at a glance the comparative output of many composers' works.
When people are a few metres away from the sphere they hear a quiet murmur, but when they approach and put their ears close to the individual speakers they are able to listen to specific compositions. The collection is inspired by American composer Charles Ives' use of simultaneity as a compositional tool.

Technically, a set of customised circuit boards can play thousands of individual channels simultaneously. The spheres are modelled algorithmically and then 3D printed in different materials according to the composer's requirements: porcelain, steel, polymer, stainless steel, and so on. Each piece is suspended from a small playback box, which hangs from the ceiling of the exhibition space.

Title: People Wood: Data Sculpture of Questionnaire Data
Description Engilish: Manor House Development Trust, a charitable social enterprise based in Hackney, commissioned Something & Son to create a sculpture at the new Redmond Community Centre in Woodbury Down, North East Hackney.Something & Son approached Inition for help in creating the sculpture, featuring a 400 Something & Son approached Inition to help create a crowdsourced data sculpture featuring a forest of over 400 3D printed trees, each corresponding to an individual's response to an online questionnaire.

Title: Quantum of Peace: Numerical Display Made with Bullets
Description Engilish: Miara Pokoju's work Quantum of Peace is an interactive installation and kinetic information sculpture commissioned by the Warsaw Uprising Museum to celebrate the 71st anniversary of the Warsaw Uprising and the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in Europe. Using thousands of bullet casings, 70 pneumatic actuators, hundreds of neodymium magnets, and five industrial-grade drive belts, the installation displays a series of figures that convey the facts of World War II and the Warsaw Rising.

Title: London Eye Chart: A 135m Tall Donut Chart
Description Engilish: A week before the 2015 UK General Election, design studio Bompas & Parr and Facebook turned the London Ferris Wheel into a giant donut map of the most discussed political parties on Facebook. Blue for the Conservatives and red for Labour.

Title: Physical Weather Display
Description Engilish:
Ken Kawamoto, a Japanese software engineer, has invented Tempescope, a device that displays weather forecasts or current weather.
Tempescope simulates the weather forecast on a computer or smartphone in real time via a wireless connection to get a better idea of the actual weather outside. Rain is simulated by droplets falling on the box, temperature is indicated by colour changing LEDs and clouds are conveyed by a fog diffuser.

Title: Solid Model of Stellar Winds
Description Engilish:
Scientists continue to use solid models to help them better understand complex 3D data (here's an astrophysics simulation): shape of the solar wind 3D printing
They say it gives them a deeper understanding of what's going on." They say, "Being able to hold and examine the 3D printed model provided a new perspective on the geometry of WWIR and improved the ability to perceive different structural scales. In particular, they say the model gave them an idea of how large the shock waves were compared to the stars and the distances between them.

Title: Accomplishments
Description Engilish:
Achievement: is an exploration of personal data tracking, wearable art, wearable technology, social media and the physicalisation of data. Every day's achievements are tracked, firstly on paper, and then through the sewing of spheres onto a dress worn for four months.
By hand-sewing each achievement onto the dress, they become part of the wearer's physical presence and identity. The work juxtaposes the immediacy of social media posts with the separate identities we create for ourselves online, which are often detached from our physical presence. The work also speaks to the use of wearable technology and the ability to track daily steps, sleep, mood and other personal information as a standard practice. This data is often shared openly online, yet these devices are often invisible due to their small size, disguised as watches, necklaces, or hidden in pockets.

Title: Adrien Segal's Data Furniture
Description Engilish:
Water Use Trends: is a data sculpture showing water use statistics for the entire United States over a 50-year period from 1950 to 2000. The width of the canyon walls represents water use. According to the USGS, each river or tributary represents a specific water use category: thermoelectric, irrigation, industrial, public water supply, domestic, and mining/aquaculture/livestock/rural (combined).
The shape of the canyon seen above is based on a map of the Colorado River (thermoelectric) and its main tributary, the Green River (irrigation), as well as three smaller tributaries - accounting for all the water (fresh and salt) withdrawn in the United States each day: 408,000 million gallons

Title: Data Sculpture in the White House
Description Engilish:
French digital artist and fab lab co-founder Gilles Azzaro created a sound sculpture of Barack Obama's 2013 State of the Union address, in which Obama referred to 3D printing as the next revolution in manufacturing.
In 2014, Azzaro's sculpture was on display at the White House during the opening of the first White House Festival of Creativity. The sculpture is interactive: motion sensors activate the system, and a laser beam scans the 3D recording to display the president's speech.

Title: Tidal Memory
Description Engilish: Tidal Memory : A full-scale display of the ever-changing daily tides. Twenty-four water-filled glass columns receive real-time data from the oldest tidal station in the Western Hemisphere, acting as a tide clock and 24-hour sculpture archive; recording hourly tide levels throughout the day starting at midnight.

Title: Temperature Scarves and Afghans
Description Engilish:
In January 2013, Kristen Cooper Nutbrown from British Columbia had the idea to create a temperature scarf, knitting a row of scarves each day in a colour that represented the temperature for that day.
At the end of the year, the scarf would visually display the local temperature readings for the entire year. Shortly after Kristin came up with her idea, Arlene Cline, also from British Columbia, started making temperature squares (blankets knitted or crocheted with wool)

Title: Mazamet Ville Morte
