Description Engilish: In 1973, the town of Mazamet, France, had a population comparable to the number of deaths caused by motor vehicles in the country the previous year. A television reporter decided to symbolise these deaths by having all the inhabitants lie on the ground.

Title: All the Submarines of the United States of America
Description Engilish: This installation by American artist Chris Burden shows 625 submarines from the US fleet from the late 1890s to the late 1980s. The cardboard models are suspended at different heights to look like a school of fish.

Title: Münster Congestion Visualization
Description Engilish: To encourage people to use buses, in 1991 the city of Münster, Germany, produced a poster comparing the space taken up by 72 bicycles (left), 72 cars (centre) and one bus (right).

Title: Rearrangeable Wooden Model of Brain Scan
Description Engilish: An anthology of magnetic resonance imaging data produced by Neil Fraser is pasted onto 60 wooden blocks, allowing physical mining of the cross sections.

Title: Mitchell Whitelaw's Weather Sculptures
Description Engilish: Weather data is another interesting option for making data jewellery, this is a bracelet by Mitchell Whitelaw based on a year's worth of weather data from Canberra.

Title: Cookbook Arranges Ingredients into Physical Visualizations
Description Engilish: In Sweden, IKEA gives away baking books where ingredients are arranged into physical visualizations. The photos are by Karl Kleiner. This idea is reminiscent of Ursus Wehrli's art projects.

Title: MRI image overlay: Application to arthrography needle insertion
Description Engilish:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers great potential for planning, guiding, monitoring and controlling interventions. Magnetic resonance arthrography (MRAr) is the imaging gold standard for assessing damage to the small joint ligaments and fibrocartilage. In contemporary practice, MRAr consists of two consecutive sessions: (1) an interventional session in which a needle is inserted into the joint space and MR contrast is injected under fluoroscopic or CT guidance; and (2) a diagnostic session of MRI imaging to visualise the distribution of the contrast within the joint space and to assess the joint condition.
Our MRAr method performs these tasks on a conventional high-field closed-field MRI scanner, thereby eliminating the separate radiographically guided needle insertion and contrast agent injection processes. We propose a 2D augmented reality image overlay device for guiding the puncture needle insertion procedure. This approach allows diagnostic high-field magnets to be used for interventions without the need for complex and expensive engineering aids. In preclinical trials, we used the magnetic resonance image superimposition guidance device to perform punctures in porcine and human cadaveric joints; in all cases, the puncture needle successfully reached the joint space on the first attempt.

Title: Infotropism: living and robotic plants as interactive displays
Description Engilish:
Designers often borrow elements from nature to achieve pleasing, unobtrusive designs. We combined living plants with sensors and lights to produce an interactive display and create a robot that mimics phototropic behaviour. This paper documents our design process and reports the results of a two-week field study.
We placed the live plant display and its corresponding robot between a pair of trash and recycling containers in the cafeteria. The placement of recyclables or trash triggered directional beams that gradually tilted the plant display towards the more active container. In interviews, people explained the reasons for the plant displays and talked about caring for the plants. There was a slight increase in people's recycling behaviour where live plants were displayed (p=.08). There was also a significant increase in people's recycling behaviour at the robotic display and at the light-only display. Our findings suggest that there is value in exploring the use of living materials and biomimetic forms in displays, as well as the use of lightweight robots to provide simple rewards.

Title: RFIG lamps: interacting with a self-describing world via photosensing wireless tags and projectors
Description Engilish:
This paper describes how the physical world can be detected in such a way that objects can describe themselves, communicating their identity, geometry and other information such as history or user annotations. The enabling technology is a wireless tag that acts as a radio frequency identity and geometry (RFIG) transponder. We show how adding a photo sensor to a wireless tag can greatly extend its functionality to enable geometric manipulation, such as finding the tag's 3D location, or detecting changes in the shape of the tagged object. Tag data is projected directly to the user by using a handheld locally aware mobile projector.
We introduce a new technique called interactive projection that allows the user to interact with the projected information, e.g. to navigate or update the projected information. However, this work is motivated by the emergence of powerless passive RFID technology, which promises to have a significant impact on real-world applications. We will discuss how current prototypes could evolve into passive RFID technology in the future.

Title: Augmented Reality for Urban Simulation Visualization
Description Engilish:
Visualisations of large-scale simulations are not only computationally intensive, but also difficult for viewers to understand due to the sheer volume of data to be processed.
The case of an urban wind flow simulation demonstrates the advantages of mobile augmented reality visualisation, both in terms of selecting data that is relevant to the user and in terms of easy and understandable access to the simulation results. This is achieved through a novel visualisation method that correctly positions the simulation results in real-world images based on current city model data.

Title: Data-in-Place: Thinking through the Relations Between Data and Community
Description Engilish:
We present the results of a year-long research study of a street and its neighbourhood. This work explores how the production and use of data is linked to place, from both a physical and social geography perspective. We detail three aspects of the project. Firstly, we explore how residents organise existing data about their street in the form of an archive, including both physical and digital content. Second, we report on efforts to capture data on the street environment, particularly vehicular traffic. Third, we draw on the possibilities offered by polling techniques.
We reflect on how these engagements: crystallise the unique relationship between communities and their data; surface the flows and contours of data, as well as spatial, temporal and social boundaries; and create a multiplicity of 'small worlds'. We will consider how this notion of 'data in place' relates to technical design.

Title: SiteLens: situated visualization techniques for urban site visits
Description Engilish:
Urban designers and city planners often conduct site visits prior to design activities to look for patterns or to better understand existing conditions. We present SiteLens, an experimental system and set of technologies that support site visits by visualising relevant virtual data directly in the physical site environment, which we call situated visualisation.
We discuss other visual representations and techniques for data collection, organisation, discovery, comparison, manipulation and provenance. We present a real-life use scenario and conducted two iterations of evaluation with faculty and students at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation to provide direction and insights for further research.

Title: A co-designed Data-Dance
Description Engilish: Data literacy is important to support individuals in incorporating research information into their own perspectives and decision-making processes. However, it can be challenging for students to read, understand, and make connections to data. Students must be able to traverse representations of data (e.g., numbers, graphs, etc.) and connect them to their understanding of a topic. We explored the implementation of a co-designed Data-Dance unit in which secondary school students created their own embodied metaphors to represent and communicate graphics through dance. Through analysing the dance work and post-school interviews with learners and teachers, we demonstrated how the creation of embodied metaphors in dance led to new ways of exploring data, and how learners were able to reflect on the theme from different perspectives with different values, contexts and meanings.

Title: Relief
Description Engilish:
Relief is a driven desktop display capable of rendering and animating three-dimensional shapes on a malleable surface. It enables users to experience and form digital models that resemble geographic terrain in an intuitive way.
The desktop surface is driven by an array of 120 motorised pins that are controlled by a platform based on open source hardware and software tools. Each pin can be handled individually and senses user inputs such as pulling and pushing.

Title: GORI.node garden
Description Engilish:
Gardening was once an art form birthed from Zen principles. It emphasises the intentional blurring of the distinction between natural and man-made materials. In order to explore the author's alternative view of the web and the idea of "node gardening", the "Gori. Node Gardening" installation project adopts this concept. Gori. Node Garden" was developed as a series of network data visualisations.
While earlier versions of 'GORI.Node Garden' utilised mobile communications data to cultivate a private network garden, 'Gardening Two' is an open network garden where anyone on the Internet can participate in growing GORI via instant messaging.This paper is a description of the second garden.

Title: Change Ringing
Description Engilish:
The sculpture uses a set of six bronze bells designed and cast by the artist Peter Shenai. Their shapes are mathematically derived from a graphical statistical representation of summer temperatures in the twentieth century at seventeen-year intervals.
The bells are arranged chronologically and struck sequentially according to the corresponding dataset, emitting a series of discordant spectra that sonically convey the story of twentieth-century climate change. The series forms the basis of a twenty-five minute work by Laurence Osborne, scored for string orchestra and the bells themselves.

Title: The World's Best Spintop
Description Engilish:
The main idea of the project is to visualise statistical data by transforming it into the shape and behaviour of an object. The object in question is a spinning gyroscope whose shape is generated from statistical data from various countries on criteria such as political environment, health, education, economic dynamism and quality of life. The data used are from sources such as the World Bank, the World Health Organisation and the Central Intelligence Agency. The statistical criteria were translated into algorithms that generated each gyroscopic structure.
The statistical data were used to determine the structural parameters of physical stability, and each gyro shows the functioning of the country represented.

Title: My Life Don't Mean a Thing if it Ain't got that Swing
Description Engilish: A usable swing set that expresses the percentage of people in different countries who are "satisfied" with their lives.

Title: Multi-Touch Querying on Data Physicalizations in Immersive AR
Description Engilish:
Data physicalisation (3D printed terrain models, anatomical scans, and even abstract data) can naturally engage the visual and tactile senses in a way that is difficult or impossible to do with traditional flat touchscreens or even immersive digital displays. However, the rigid 3D physicalisation produced by today's most common 3D printers fundamentally limits data exploration and querying tasks that require dynamic inputs (e.g., touch sensing) and outputs (e.g., animation) that can be easily handled by digital displays. We introduce a novel hybrid virtual+physical visualisation style specifically designed to support interactive data exploration tasks.
To achieve a "best of both worlds" solution, our approach combines immersive AR, physical 3D data printouts and touch sensing through physicalisation. We demonstrate that the solution can support the three most common spatial data query interactions used in scientific visualisation (streamline seeding, dynamic cut location and micro-world visualisation). Finally, we present quantitative performance data and describe the first application of an exploratory visualisation of supercomputer climate simulation data that is actively being investigated with feedback from scientists in the field.

Title: Cardiomorphologies
Description Engilish: George Khut and his collaborators' Cardiac Morphology series explores subjective spaces created by interacting with simple geometric visualisations of real-time heart rate and respiratory rate data. The installation consists of a large floor-to-ceiling video projection controlled by the heart and respiratory signals of a participant sitting a few metres away.

Title: StressTree: A Metaphorical Visualization for Biofeedback-assisted Stress Management
Description Engilish:
In today's competitive environment, chronic stress is one of the leading causes of health problems. To address this issue, biofeedback techniques have been used to aid relaxation training and stress management. In this paper, we present "StressTree" - a metaphorical visualisation of heart rate variability (HRV) biofeedback system.The aim of StressTree is to present HRV data in a more vivid and meaningful way in the context of stress management.
The HRV biofeedback system consists of a heartbeat data acquisition unit, a data analysis unit and a visualisation unit. Feedback from interviews in the evaluation indicated that the StressTree could show different patterns of increase during intense work or relaxation training. Participants found the biofeedback interactions through the StressTree to be clear and engaging, giving them a strong motivation to regulate their breathing patterns to achieve a 'healthy' tree shape.

Title: ESSYS* Sharing #UC
Description Engilish:
In this paper we present ESSYS* Sharing #UC, an audio visual art installation about online sharing involving tweets about the University of Coimbra and the city. The artwork was commissioned by the Interdisciplinary Institute of the University of Coimbra (UC) and was designed to celebrate the 730th anniversary of the UC. The installation is hybrid in nature, accessible in both physical art gallery and online spaces.
In both installation spaces, one can see a set of generated typographic poster designs displaying Coimbra-related tweets accompanied by changing ambient sounds. The viewer indirectly influences the audio visual generation of the installation through the tweets, affecting the character of the multimedia artefacts created and displayed.

Title: Grewingk Glacier
Description Engilish:
Grubinck Glacier
DATA SOURCE: Kachemak Bay Research Reserve/Alaska Department of Fish and Game
Glacier map courtesy of Steve Baird, GIS Research Analyst Gruwink Glacier is an ephemeral data sculpture in the form of a map of the terminus of the Gruwink Glacier as it retreated over a 150-year period. Located in Kachemak Bay on Alaska's Kenai Peninsula, Gruewink Glacier is part of the much larger Harding Ice Sheet, a vast ice sheet that has spawned 40 glaciers over 300 square miles. Aerial maps based on photographic and satellite imagery show glacier perimeters in 1952, 1985, 1996, 2003 and 2008. On average, Gruewink Glacier retreats 92 feet per year.

Title: Taste Map Edinburgh
Description Engilish:
Scotland is a beautiful little European country without the problem of an ageing population. Scots die young and do not guard their pensions for decades like Japanese centenarians, sucking the blood out of the younger generation. What is their secret? The Scottish diet, an age-old combination of low intake of fresh fruit and vegetables and high intake of sweets, high-fat meat products, sweets and savoury snacks, accompanied by plenty of sugary drinks and alcohol." The golden rule of the Scottish diet is that fat, sugar and alcohol each make up at least 30 per cent of your daily calorie intake. You can have one portion of fruit a week, preferably jam or preserves." 
Fat creates an elevation chart showing the cumulative fat calories consumed during the day.

Title: Smellmap: Paris
Description Engilish:
My scent landscape mapping artworks began as an exploration of the connection between place, odour and emotion. I predicted that the smells of Paris would evoke the smells of other cities around the world, but the sensitive, subtle, everyday 'scent notes' of viewers disproved my predictions.

Extensive research has shown that the scent of coffee causes people to tell a story, the smell of perfume causes people to refer to other people, and wine is most likely to remind people of events they have attended. The location may be very specific (the front room of Grandma's house) or very general (a railway station). The degree of emotion varies and is difficult to measure.

Title: Milan Smells
Description Engilish: This is a Milano scent map that incorporates the odors from or around Milan's iconic buildings. This device includes hand-painted buildings, and the diffuser inside the building emits a homemade fragrance. Imagine the smells of nightclubs (G&T), restaurants (tomatoes and basil), Peace Arch (grass), Milano Aquarium (fish food), Skara Opera House (incense), and Last Supper (chocolate and strawberries). The audience graffiti on the map and buildings to answer.

Title: Ellesmere port's Scentscape
Description Engilish:
On a weekend in July, Elsmere Port held three sensory discovery hiking trips. Local residents and workers have rediscovered the Port of Elsmere from different perspectives, gaining an understanding of the people and events here. From freshly baked bread and cut grass to BO, a 45 minute hike showcases a whole new world.

Participants assign colors and shapes to each odor, giving it a physical form and transforming their perception of intangible odors into visual effects. On a blank map, personal perceptions are nailed in the form of scent notes. Each participant on the Elsmere Port odor map has an odor note with an "odor sketch" attached, sometimes drawn by the participants and sometimes interpreted by the designer.

On the odor map of Port Elsmere, people experience different colors of odors: the Rivakrik Valley Nature Reserve has a green odor (related to the color of the surrounding environment? The colors of industrial plants located outside the city range from blue, sludge to gray, but often appear in the form of clouds).

Title: Move&Find: The Value of Kinaesthetic Experience in a Casual Data Representation
Description Engilish:
In this article, we introduce Move&Find, a device that allows users to experience the energy required for conducting Google searches. Users can only receive their search results when they exert an effort equal to the energy required to search by riding a bicycle (see Figure 1).

Move&Find is a type of multisensory data expression, referred to by Hogan and Hornecker as "a type of data expression that explicitly intends to reveal insight by encoding data in multiple expression modes, and requires at least two sensory channels to fully interpret and understand underlying data" (page 3). More specifically, Move&Find encodes the energy required for Google search by the force required to move the bicycle's rear wheels (i.e. the number of rotations of the wheels). A tablet computer was installed in front of the bicycle, displaying a visualization of the distance traveled. Although the relevant data is encoded in the visual and physical properties of Move&Find, it is only revealed when the user interacts with the device. Only a sporty experience can reveal the data it represents. In order to gain a deeper understanding of the value of this sporty experience, we have raised a more specific question: What is the value expressed by the multisensory data in Move&Find compared to the same device that lacks a sporty experience?

Title: InterANTARCTICA
Description Engilish:
Inter ANTARCTICA is an installation created, designed, and guided by Caitilin de Berigny, and created by a team of artists. Inter ANTARCTICA provides a technological platform for the public to interact, experience, and acquire important knowledge about climate change. The focus of this concept is on the largest ice block on Earth - Antarctica. Our motivation stems from the urgent need to understand what is known as the greatest challenge and threat to humanity: climate change.

Entering the exhibition space, the audience is surrounded by a three screen video installation showcasing the Antarctic landscape. Viewers can hear Antarctic music created by other viewers in real-time interaction. Inter ANTARCTICA relies on audience interaction, that is, audience control and creation of sound. By creating sounds, viewers can engage in additional interaction by modifying the visualization. Inter ANTARCTICA helps audiences understand important scientific data through multisensory experiences (sound, vision, touch).

Title: RisingEMOTIONS
Description Engilish:
RisingEMOTIONS is a collaborative art project that combines digital technology with public art to create a highly localized artwork that visualizes the emotions of the public caused by rising sea levels. This artwork utilizes an easily accessible customized online survey to collect information on the feelings of residents of East Boston towards the impact of rising sea levels in their community. Their reactions and emotions are visualized and transformed into an art installation, using color bands to represent future flood levels in the background of the Boston Public Library East Boston branch. Encourage participants in online surveys to participate in ongoing government and grassroots efforts around resilience. This project attempts to pilot a new hybrid model that combines art and social technology for data collection and visualization, promoting fair resilience and inclusive planning by increasing public participation.

The device consists of a ribbon placed on a steel frame in front of the East Boston branch of the Boston Public Library. These straps pass through the terrace and press upwards against the windows of the building. The height of the frames and lines on the building represents the height at which 1% of the annual flood is expected to occur at this specific location in 2070 (approximately 3.7 feet). This data was provided by the Boston Sustainable Solutions Laboratory at the University of Massachusetts.

The project asked residents how they feel about the severe impact of floods caused by climate change on East Boston. Their answers are color coded into five emotions: care, optimism, anger, sadness, and others. Care is represented in blue, optimism in yellow, anger in red, sadness in deep blue, and others in green. Over 150 residents participated in the online survey within two weeks. Their responses showed that the majority of people felt worried (51%), followed by optimism (17%), sadness (14%), anger (9%), and "other" (9%). Local students and residents will copy some excerpts of the answers left by the participants on ribbons.

Title: Core Sample – 2007
Description Engilish:
The Core Sample is an interactive sound stroll and corresponding sound sculpture based on the Global Positioning System, evoking the material and cultural history contained and implied in the landscape of Glasses Island. The work involves an extension of the landscape of Boston Port, which is composed of the new buildings of the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art and Spectacle Island located on the downtown waterfront. Glasses Island is a former landfill and landfill park, clearly visible on the coast. These two locations have a dialogue function, questioning what is seen and what is unseen, preserved and recorded, as well as what is suppressed and denied.

Tourists can take the Island Express ferry from Long Pier for 15 minutes to reach Glasses Island, and can borrow earphones for free at the Glasses Island Visitor Center. The sound will automatically play based on each tourist's unique itinerary. The theme sound content changes with the altitude contour of the path system, implying the vertical hierarchy of the metaphorical core sample (see installation map). Abstract sounds and spoken language blur the surface and core, nature and artificial, industry and organic, past, present, and future.

The installation also exists at the Founder's Gallery of the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art, where a 99 foot sound sculpture appears as an architectural element, installed along the length of the gallery, providing a panoramic view of Boston Harbor.

Title: News-Feed
Description Engilish:
News Feed is a data visualization and sound art installation that reveals the emotions of published news stories by reading major online newspapers worldwide. When new articles are published in major journals, the VADER algorithm analyzes and categorizes them based on their positive or negative emotions. Then explain these results and transform them into sound and visual meanings, so that the audio-visual devices and data can be represented accordingly.

"NEWS FEED" is a triple device consisting of a sound sculpture (Figure 3), a display screen and projection (Figure 2), and a visual projection (Figure 1). The sound sculpture will sound the article being read, the display screen and projection will display the current news story being read and analyzed, and the visual projection will map the data to visual meaning.

The plan of the exhibition is to allow the audience to first see and hear sound installations, then visualize them, and finally display or wait for analysis of text/news reports. In this way, the audience first enters the work through sensory experience, and then overcomes sensory experience in the background of the news story, thus establishing a dialogue between the three works.

Title: A conversation between trees: what data feels like in the forest
Description Engilish: Research on an interactive artwork shows how artists engage the public in scientific climate change data. This artwork visualizes real-time environmental data collected from distant trees along with historical and predicted global carbon dioxide data. Visitors also participated in the mobile sensing experience in the nearby forest. Our research reveals how works are designed and experienced from the perspectives of artists, visitors, and a climate scientist. We have found that artists employ a unique approach to promote emotional engagement in data, rather than information or persuasion. We described the performance strategies they adopted to achieve this goal, including sensory involvement in data, balancing vivid and slow time structures, and juxtaposing different data processing methods to achieve interpretation and dialogue.

Title: Red balloon, green balloon, sensors in the sky
Description Engilish:
Wonder computing is a novel strategy that utilizes expressive tangible media to vividly project information into the public domain. We demonstrated an example of this calculation mode using large glowing balloons that change color based on the input from the attached air quality sensors (exhaust gas, diesel, or volatile organic compounds). In the deployment of two public facilities (urban streets and public parks) and six ordinary citizens, we invite stakeholders to engage in gamified exploration and actively participate in visualizing the surrounding air quality.
We also made a DIY kit, which includes a printed circuit board, electronic components, and instructions for making air quality balloons. At a seminar, six non professional users successfully assembled functional balloons, validating our technology as a DIY tool for visualizing public air quality. Our deployment and seminar emphasized that games and wonders are fundamental elements of public participation and activism. We have outlined design guidelines for future wonder computing projects that involve stakeholders in environmental data and empower them to change urban landscapes.

Title:
Street infographics: Raising
Awareness of Local Issues through a Situated Urban Visualization
Description Engilish:
In our public visualization "Street Infographics", we attach leisure information visualization boards to existing street signs in the medium-sized city of Leuven, Belgium. Here, the planning of student residential areas has raised concerns about uneven distribution among students, foreigners, and permanent residents. Our goal is to inform residents of the actual situation of the social population composition.
Therefore, we collected social and demographic data for four specific streets and visualized two data dimensions, namely the number of permanent residents and whether they are locals. We distributed these data dimensions of street residents by categorizing 100 information icons (Figure 1). The visual graphic design imitates the characteristics of street signs in terms of color scheme, font selection, and physical size. The back of each logo clearly indicates the actual data source. By attaching visualization to existing street signs, we cleverly broke through the daily environment. Although the visualization does not explicitly specify the location of the data representation, attaching it to existing street signs implies that it is information for that specific street. We have visualized the four adjacent streets, allowing passersby to explore other signs of the surrounding environment for data-based comparison.

Title: Projection bombing a neighborhood with visualization
Description Engilish:
The data is based on a 2012 local survey showing the top five prevalent issues in this specific community. The overall goal of intervention is to inform residents of the actual situation regarding several epidemic issues, encourage them to reflect on these issues, and trigger social discussions in the community. The data was collected from the local government [1] and visualized as a star chart with 9 data dimensions, namely income, green space area, health, migration, foreign born citizens, illegal dumping, retail sales, neighborhood connections, idle time, and average age, each dimension depicted as a unique star chart. The main visualization displays several statistical data of the local community. This representation is compared through 8 smaller star charts, each representing the same data for 8 nearby communities in the same city. Three eye-catching qualitative comments from the local community regarding one of the issues were displayed, such as "This region may become too expensive for ordinary people.". The star chart visualization and referencing alternate through animated transitions, and the data source is clearly visible on the projection.
We used a mobile projector powered by a car battery, car, Raspberry Pi, and projector. Due to its physical size of approximately 3 meters by 3 meters and its extraordinary location in urban environments, the projection is particularly eye-catching. We have never announced when and where to deploy the projection, sometimes appearing in multiple areas simultaneously in one night. We project onto an abandoned factory surrounded by cafes and restaurants in the middle of the community. In the coming months, this factory will be demolished, raising concerns among locals about the new use of the space. For those who understand this issue, visualization seems to be related to it, as some data dimensions involve opportunities for redevelopment, such as limited green space and uneven income distribution. However, even without understanding this issue, visualization is always easy to understand, relevant, and meaningful.

Title: Claes: Public Visualization Street Art
Description Engilish:
Here, we did not start from existing local issues, as we aim to explore the interests of citizens by providing them with a series of datasets. The overall purpose of our design is to enable citizens to explore their cities from a data centric perspective and encourage them to find meaningful connections between the displayed data and statistical data.
The appearance of this device is similar to the preliminary prototype; It doesn't look exquisite, but highlights the typical bottom-up, DIY characteristics of temporary intervention. Its physical design is similar to urban telescopes, both familiar and unfamiliar, enough to arouse the curiosity of passersby. The external height of the device is 1.80 meters, width is 0.30 meters, and depth is 0.60 meters. Inside the device, people are invited to explore ten different datasets, such as birth rate, number of residents, unemployment rate, number of beneficiaries, vulnerable groups, number of parks, amount of waste, income, energy use, and CO2 emissions. We have generated a time series line chart for each dataset, spanning from 2003 to 2011, which has been normalized for accurate comparison. The graphic lines are engraved on a transparent Plexiglas (30 x 30 cm) board. Each board is labeled with its dataset title and information source. The telescope itself is equipped with three slots, allowing users to insert a board, view the telescope through the inserted transparent board, and then compare up to three datasets. There is no clear visualization indicating where the data comes from, which leads to some vague reflections (such as, is it data about the entire country, province, or city?). However, the obvious telescope metaphor encourages passersby to further explain the environmental background and associate visualization with their environment.

Title: Hypertension Singing Bowl
Description Engilish:
This stainless steel bowl is made based on a year's blood pressure reading. Hypertension is known as the "silent killer" due to its lack of symptoms, and it is an important factor in many life-threatening diseases.
For centuries, the song bowl has been associated with reducing stress and maintaining health. The antique bowl is handmade from alloys of up to seven metals, which may include gold, silver, mercury, copper, iron, tin, lead, zinc, nickel, and other trace elements. The handcrafted shape and alloy mean that each bowl has its own unique distinctive color tone. Nowadays, bronze cast singing bowls are more uniform in shape, material, and sound.
The shape of the hypertension bowl is constructed through computer-aided design based on blood pressure readings, resulting in personalized and unique shapes. Then digitize this shape using stainless steel to create an acoustic object that produces a tone when rubbed against a wooden "puja" rod.
The acoustic characteristics of singing bowls vary from person to person. The upper part of the singing bowl is shaped based on daily systolic blood pressure, while the lower part is shaped based on daily diastolic blood pressure. The meditation sound it produces is not only a means of reducing stress, but also reminds people to monitor their health status and cultivate a healthy lifestyle.

Title: Data as Delight: Eating data
Description Engilish:
Data can bring joy in the form of beverages. The system "TasyBeats" [49] was inspired by sports drinks, aiming to provide people with appropriate amounts of ingredients to supplement their physical needs during and after exercise, and was inspired by bartenders' performative displays of mixed drinks.

In this system, the heart rate sensor captures physical activity, and once participants want to quench their thirst, the system (Figure 2) uses up to four ingredients to mix personalized drinks (see [49] for technical details). Based on the duration of time the participant's heart rate stays between 60 and 95 beats per minute, the system drives a liquid pump to "spray" ingredients into the cup. The system design inspiration comes from the exaggerated actions of bartenders pouring alcohol from bottles (such as pouring from a height).

If the participant's heart rate is between 96 and 130 beats per minute, the system will add lightly seasoned water. If the heart rate is between 131 and 165, the system will add electrolyte containing liquid. Finally, if the heart rate is between 166 and 195, the system will add water with a strong taste. All the personalized beverages generated by these responses are inspired by data in terms of taste and recovery benefits. Related studies [49] indicate that participants find that systematic "performance" contributes to a pleasant experience of interacting with their physical activity data.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
Unlike the trend of constantly breaking records in the men's 100m at the Olympics, Bob Bimon set a world record of 8.9 meters (29 feet 2.5 inches) in the long jump event in 1968 and still holds the Olympic record until Mike Powell won the world record with a time of 8.95 meters (29 feet 4.25 inches) in 1991.
Like the story of the men's 100 meter sprint at the Olympics, Bob Bimon's Olympic long jump [44] is presented through video and visualization, not only highlighting Bimon's performance relative to his peers, but also showcasing the amazing distances these athletes can jump: comparable to the distance of the basketball three-point line (Figure 4a). This comparison helps people better understand these distances, but what if someone has never played basketball or even stepped on a basketball court? Of course, more familiar references can be used [24], but visualizing these distances at a realistic scale will allow users to experience them firsthand.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
Usain Bolt held the world record for the men's 100 meters at the 2012 London Olympics with a time of 9.63 seconds. The New York Times' One Race, Every Medalist Every [45] compared Bolt's results to those of all Olympic medalists since 1896, placing this achievement in a broader context.
A virtual environment was created on a real-world scale (Figure 3b). Users can play, pause, and restart races, allowing each sprinter to run along the track at their average speed. Initially, we used simple human sized cubes to represent sprinters (Figure 3c), but later replaced them with anatomical 3D models.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
In the Visualization of US Debt in US $100 Banknotes, a huge amount (more than US $20 trillion in 2017) that is difficult to understand was visualized using a specific scale.
Starting from a single $100 bill and moving to a tray of $100 million worth of bills each, this work ultimately compares these trays of bills with other large objects, such as the Statue of Liberty in Figure 8a, to showcase the enormous amount of debt.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
The protest march on the streets of Hong Kong in 2019 involved over 2 million people. To help visualize the massive scale of this event, The New York Times spliced several bird's-eye photos between June 16 and June 30, 2019, forming a vertical composite image and presented it in a scrolling format.
It combines the small size of each individual with seemingly endless photos to achieve this effect.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
There are many graphics, visualizations, and videos aimed at popularizing the enormous scale of our solar system to people. One example focuses on the astonishing distance between the Earth and the Moon. It illustrates this by showing how all other planets can be located between the two when their average distances are separated.
This presents a challenge we want to investigate: the impact of rescaling and transforming on the experience in virtual reality.

Title: Data Visceralization: Enabling Deeper Understanding of Data Using Virtual Reality
Description Engilish:
A common visualization method when comparing the physical dimensions of related objects or organisms is to use comparison charts. This compares each subject to a 2D image or contour, typically represented by the y-axis for height. One common application is the comparison of skyscrapers.
This method is very suitable for understanding the relative sizes between objects (for example, Elbruce Mountain, Kilimanjaro Mountain, and Denali Mountain are roughly equal in altitude), but it does not indicate the absolute size of each subject (i.e., what it feels like to stand at the foot of a mountain about 6 kilometers or 3.7 miles high).

Title: Citizen Dialogue Kit: Public Polling and Data Visualization Displays for Bottom-Up Citizen Participation
Description Engilish: In this presentation, the author introduces ongoing research on how to utilize scenario visualization of open and citizen science data in public spaces to provide information to citizens and engage them. The author has developed an open-source toolkit called the Citizen Dialogue Toolkit, which can convey visual data on a set of wireless networked interactive displays that can be freely located in urban space. This toolkit includes a set of participatory methods to guide stakeholders in selecting and designing data visualization, a set of ready-made hardware components, and customized open-source software to control the entire system.

Title: Situated Analytics: Demonstrating immersive analytical tools with Augmented Reality
Description Engilish:
Using augmented reality technology as an immersive analysis tool in the physical world. The author introduces Situated Analytics, a novel combination of real-time interaction and visualization technologies that allow for the exploration and analysis of object information in a user's physical environment. Situated Analytics can present both situational information to users and abstract summaries and contextual information.
The author's user research evaluated its usage in three shopping analysis tasks and compared the usage of scenario analysis prototypes with manual analysis. The results indicate that compared to manual analysis methods, users prefer to use scenario analysis prototypes, and using scenario analysis prototypes can complete tasks faster and more accurately.

Title: MelissAR: Towards Augmented Visual Analytics of Honey Bee Behaviour
Description Engilish:
MelissAR is an augmented reality system used for visual analysis of bee behavior in the wild. The system aims to support bee breeders and other relevant users in monitoring bee populations and making effective decisions based on bee conditions.
The implementation of MelissAR is based on wise design choices in terms of on-site availability, effective communication of relevant information, and robustness under different outdoor conditions.

Title: Augmented Situated Visualization for Spatial and Context-Aware Decision-Making
Description Engilish:
When entering indoor spaces such as classrooms or auditoriums, people may try to analyze and choose a suitable place to stay during activities. This may require considering multiple standards, and most standards are not always self-evident or insignificant. This work suggests using a combination of data visualization and augmented reality (AR) user interface to help users determine the most convenient seat. We considered any set of requirements and projected the information directly onto the top of the seats and around the room. Users can also narrow down their search range by switching and combining displayed attributes such as temperature and wheelchair accessibility.
In the availability assessment of seat selection tasks for a group of 16 users, the proposed method was tested with comparable two-dimensional interactive visualization of the same data to validate the solution. Qualitative and quantitative data indicate that solutions based on augmented reality technology have broad prospects, indicating that augmented reality technology can help users make more accurate decisions, even in ordinary daily tasks. Our research findings on enhancing situational visualization have opened up new avenues for exploring situational awareness data.

Title: Building with Data: Architectural Models as Inspiration for Data Physicalization
Description Engilish:
This work explores the role of physical scale models in the architectural design process, and applies architectural insights to the creation and use of data physicalization. Based on a survey of architectural literature on model making and interviews with ten practicing architects, the author describes the role of physical models as a tool for exploration and communication.
Through these observations, the author discovered trends in the use of physical models in architecture, which may provide reference for the design of data physicalization. The author has identified four functions of architectural modeling that can be directly used to build rich data models. Finally, the author will discuss how the visualization field can apply observations from architecture to new data physical design.

Title: Augmented situated visualization methods towards electromagnetic compatibility testing
Description Engilish:
In the field of electrical engineering, hardware experts often need to analyze electromagnetic radiation data to detect any external interference or abnormal situations. The field of studying such evaluations is called Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC). As a method to support electromagnetic compatibility analysis, we recommend using Enhanced Scenario Visualization (ASV) to provide visual and interactive information for professionals, helping them understand this data and place it in the most relevant position in the spatial environment. Users can interact with visualization, change the displayed attributes, compare the overlap of multiple fields, and extract data to improve the search. In a series of data extraction evaluations conducted with users, comparable 2D and 3D interactive visualizations of the same data were tested to validate the proposed solution in this work.
The results indicate that there is a trade-off between correctness and time in the interaction methods. Hand based techniques (hand sliders and touch lenses) are the least prone to errors, with an error rate close to half that of line of sight based methods. Touching the lens is also the least time-consuming method, with an average time consumption of less than half of other methods. Among the visualization methods tested, the 2D ray casting method has a higher usability score and a lower workload index than the 3D topology view, but the error rate exposed is more than twice that of the 3D topology view.

Title: Designing a Multi-Agent Occupant Simulation System to Support Facility Planning and Analysis for COVID-19
Description Engilish:
The COVID-19 pandemic has changed human life, forcing us to rethink our building environment, design, and even behavior. Multiple stakeholders, including designers, facility managers, and policy makers, are making decisions to reduce the spread of SARS-CoV-2 virus and make our environment safer; However, there is currently a lack of effective and interactive systems for evaluating the spread of viruses in physical space.
To fill this gap, the author proposes the OccSim system, which can automatically generate occupancy behavior in building 3D models, helping users analyze the potential impact of virus transmission from a large-scale and vertical perspective. The participatory evaluation conducted by the author and four groups of stakeholders showed that OccSim can identify specific risks of virus transmission in advance and elucidate the relationship between each risk and complex human building interactions, thereby improving their decision-making process. The author reflected on the design and discussed the potential impact of OccSim in the fields of design evaluation, generative design, and digital twins.

Title: Duopography: using back-of-device multi-touch input to manipulate spatial data on mobile tangible interactive topography
Description Engilish:
Duography is a double-sided mobile tangible interface used for spatial representation and terrain manipulation. The three-dimensional solid terrain front of Duography is a tangible interface that can be directly sketched on the three-dimensional terrain or visually enhanced.
At the same time, the back of Duography's flat device supports gesture operations that are difficult to achieve on irregular fronts, allowing for the use of commonly used interactive techniques such as translation and pinching. We have provided a prototype and conducted a preliminary evaluation of the double-sided topology interface that combines 3D printing front and flat back devices.

Title: Towards an Understanding of Situated AR Visualization for Basketball Free-Throw Training
Description Engilish:
This is an observational study that compares real-time visualization of the same location and real-time visualization of scenarios in basketball free throw training. The goal is to understand the advantages and problems of applying immersive visualization to skill based sports training in the real world, and to provide insights for designing AR sports training systems.
The author designed a three-dimensional visualization scenario on a head mounted display and a two-dimensional visualization scenario on a shared display to provide real-time visual feedback for the player's shooting performance. By conducting an in subject research design on experienced basketball shooters, the author identified the characteristics of user goals, reported qualitative training experiences, and compared quantitative training results. The author's research findings indicate that real-time visual feedback helps athletes improve their subsequent shooting. In the study, the shooter achieved higher angle consistency through our visual feedback. In addition, AR visualization can also promote athletes to pay more attention to their body shape. Finally, the author provides suggestions for the design of future sports AR research.

Title: Enhancing the Shopping Experience with Ambient Displays: A Field Study in a Retail Store
Description Engilish: This article discusses the prototype implementation of environmental display and the results of an empirical study conducted in a retail store. It regards shopping as an application area of Environmental Intelligence (AmI) technology. The prototype includes an environmental store map that enhances the perception of customer activities. The research results indicate the potential and challenges of using AmI technology to improve the shopping experience. The author further discusses the challenges and future development of applying AmI technology to shopping environments.

Title: Time-Turner: Data Engagement Through Everyday Objects in the Home
Description Engilish:
Families enjoy capturing digital media in their daily lives and replaying exciting moments, but achieving this is not an easy task. To explore this design space, the author created a physical, environmental, and situational visualization prototype called Time Turner, specifically designed for home environments, which can record home activity videos and allow families to review past activities.
The author reported on the design requirements, design principles, and the impact of this work on future design researchers.

Title: Immersive visualization with bar graphics
Description Engilish:
Augmented reality (AR) makes it possible to create immersive localization visualizations. These visualizations integrate with the real world, allowing users to perceive virtual objects as if they actually exist. The author proposes two novel immersive visualization methods for geospatial quantitative point data, which connect AR bar charts in real environments with virtual AR charts or maps. The self centered bar chart combines virtual bars placed in real landscapes with virtual 360 ° bar charts arranged around users. A circular map with bars combines the bars in the real landscape with a 360 ° virtual map that displays bar charts. These visualization designs are used to examine the position and attributes of individual points, as well as to understand the spatial and non spatial patterns of a set of points.
We conducted a study involving 12 participants to evaluate the reading accuracy and efficiency of these two visualizations, observed at a skyscraper in the center of the Melbourne metropolitan area. In order to better control for confounding factors, this study used virtual environments instead of AR settings. We found that compared to the bars placed in the landscape, the two suggestions had better visualization effects and received positive feedback from the study participants. In terms of estimation and comparison, the self centered bar chart visualization is the most accurate, while the circular map display with bars also has potential room for improvement. Our results demonstrate the potential of AR technology in conveying geospatial point data in outdoor environments through immersive bar charts.

Title: VISGIS: Dynamic situated visualization for geographic information systems
Description Engilish:
The situated visualization of geographic information system (GIS) data faces a series of problems, such as limited visibility, readability, cluttered information, and limited understanding of spatial relationships.
The author utilizes a set of dynamic scene visualization techniques to solve the challenges of visibility, information clutter, and spatial relationship understanding. These technologies can meet the special needs of geographic information system data scene visualization, especially the "street view" perspective used in many navigation applications. The proposed techniques include dynamic annotation placement, dynamic label alignment, and occlusion removal. The author applies these technologies to two types of scene visualization: augmented reality visualization and indirect augmented reality using 360 degree lenses.

Title: HydrogenAR: Interactive Data-Driven Presentation of Dispenser Reliability
Description Engilish:
When presenting to the same audience in the same location, we usually use slides with text and two-dimensional graphics to supplement oral narration. Although most of the demonstrations are conducted on two-dimensional media, augmented reality technology (AR) allows demonstration designers to add data and enhanced features to existing physical infrastructure. This coupling can provide viewers with a more attractive experience and aid in understanding. Through HydrogenAR, we demonstrate a novel application that utilizes data-driven storytelling and the advantages of AR to explain the unique challenges faced by hydrogen distributor reliability. By utilizing physical props, on-site data, virtual enhancements, and animations, HydrogenAR can serve as a unique demonstration tool that is particularly important for stakeholders, tour groups, and VIPs.
HydrogenAR is a product of multiple collaborative design iterations with local hydrogen fuel research teams, evaluating the usability and quality of interactive AR experiences through interviews with team members and user research on end users. Through this work, we provided design considerations for AR data-driven presentations and discussed how to utilize AR for innovative content delivery beyond traditional slide presentations.

Title: Virtual Vouchers: Prototyping a Mobile Augmented Reality User Interface for Botanical Species Identification
Description Engilish:
The menu plays an important role in both information display and system control. We have explored the design space of the shake menu, which is designed for tangible augmented reality. The shake menu is a radial menu displayed around the object, activated by shaking the object. An important aspect of its design space is the coordinate system used to display menu options.
We conducted an intra subject user study comparing the speed and effectiveness of several alternative methods (world reference, display reference, and object reference) for displaying shake menus in augmented reality, as well as a baseline technique (linear menu on clipboard). Our research findings demonstrate a trade-off between speed, efficiency, and interaction flexibility, and point out the potential advantages of hybrid methods for combining transformations in different coordinate systems. Finally, we described the qualitative feedback during use and introduced several example applications of this technology.

Title: Designing for Mobile and Immersive Visual Analytics in the Field
Description Engilish:
On site data collection and analysis are crucial for actions in areas such as environmental science and public safety. However, on-site staff currently face data and platform related issues when efficiently collecting and analyzing data on site, such as limited connectivity, screen space, and attention resources. In this article, we explore how visual analysis tools can change on-site practices by integrating data more deeply into these operations. We use a design probe that combines mobile, cloud, and immersive analysis components to guide interviews with ten experts from five fields, exploring how visual analysis can support on-site data collection and analysis needs. The shortcomings of the current method were identified, and target scenarios and design considerations were determined for future on-site analysis systems.
We have reflected these findings in FieldView, a scalable open-source prototype designed to support key use cases for on-site analysis. Our research findings indicate that combining mobile technology and immersive technology can improve the practicality of data in various field operations, and point out new directions for visual analysis tools to change field work.

Title: Revisited: Comparison of Empirical Methods to Evaluate Visualizations Supporting Crafting and Assembly Purposes
Description Engilish:
The ubiquity, localization, and physical visualization provide new possibilities for contextualizing tasks in the real world, such as doctors inserting needles. In the development process of situational visualization, evaluation visualization is a core requirement. However, conducting such assessments is difficult in practical scenarios, as real-world scenarios often involve safety critical or expensive testing. To overcome these issues, researchers and practitioners have adopted classic methods from ubiquitous computing and used alternative empirical methods such as augmented reality (AR), virtual reality (VR) prototypes, or online demonstrations only.
The main assumption of this method is that meaningful insights can also be obtained from different, usually cheaper, and less cumbersome empirical methods. However, recent efforts by the Human Computer Interaction (HCI) community have found evidence against this hypothesis, which may hinder the use of alternative empirical methods. Currently, these insights are based on a single survey of four interacting objects. The goal of this study is to investigate whether these previous findings are also applicable to situational visualization. Therefore, we first created a scenario where situational visualization supports users to perform DIY tasks such as handcrafting and assembly. Then, we set up five empirical research methods to evaluate these four tasks using online surveys as well as VR, AR, laboratory, and in situ studies. Through this research design, we conducted a new study with a total of 60 participants. Our results show that the situation visualization investigated in this study is not easily affected by the same dependence on empirical methods found in previous work. Our study is the first to demonstrate that analyzing situational visualization through different empirical (surrogate) methods may yield comparable results.

Title: Uplift: A Tangible and Immersive Tabletop System for Casual Collaborative Visual Analytics
Description Engilish:
Collaborative visual analysis utilizes social interaction to support data exploration and meaning construction. These processes are typically envisioned as formal, ongoing activities involving a group of professional experts who are proficient in using complex data analysis tools. However, there are many professional fields that can benefit from supporting brief data exploration among a subset of stakeholders with broad knowledge backgrounds. This "informal collaboration" scenario will require eye-catching features to attract user attention, as well as an intuitive "anytime, anywhere" interface. This article introduces Uplift, a novel prototype system aimed at supporting "informal collaborative visual analysis" of campus microgrids, designed in collaboration with local stakeholders. Through guided seminars with key members of the building management team, it was revealed that relevant knowledge is distributed among multiple experts in their team, each using specialized analytical tools.
Uplift combines captivating 3D models with central desktop display, providing intuitive and tangible interaction, as well as augmented reality and aerial data visualization, to support informal collaborative visual analysis in this complex field. During and after prototype development, evaluations were conducted on professional stakeholders in the fields of building management and energy, and the results showed that Uplift was successful as a prominent background for informal collaboration. Experts believe that such a system has high potential in gathering diverse knowledge holders, revealing its domain structure, and complex interactions in operations and finance. Such systems also have further potential in other fields that require collaborative discussions or models, predictions, or cost-benefit analysis demonstrations among senior stakeholders.

Title: Uplift: A Tangible and Immersive Tabletop System for Casual Collaborative Visual Analytics
Description Engilish:
We have utilized mature physical scale models in architecture and discovered new opportunities to interactively visualize and examine multiple geospatial data streams using these models. Due to the limitations of various data types and the limited space for possible visual encoding design, overlaying, comparing, or integrating complementary datasets in the same physical space often presents challenges in visualization. Our "synchronous world" vision is based on physical models, which dynamically and concurrently integrate visualizations of multiple data streams. To explore the potential of this concept, we conducted three design explorations using a lighting campus model to integrate visual information on building energy use, climate, and movement paths in university campuses.
We adopted a research through design approach and documented how our interdisciplinary collaborations with domain experts, students, and architects provided information for our designs. Based on our observations, we have described the advantages of the model in the following aspects: 1) localization visualization; 2) Composition visualization; 3) Operate and write visualizations. Our work highlights the potential of physical models in enabling embodied exploration of spatial and non spatial visualization through fluid interaction.

Title: TimeTables: Embodied Exploration of Immersive Spatio-Temporal Data
Description Engilish:
TimeTables is a novel prototype system aimed at utilizing the representation of spatiotemporal cubes in virtual reality to support data exploration. TimeTables uses multiple spatiotemporal cubes on a virtual desktop, allowing users to create new desktop views by extracting time layers or individual buildings. The surrounding environment includes a large space that can accommodate multiple connected tablets and a storage wall. TimeTables delve deeper into time by stretching layers, presenting information at different time scales.
Users can also jump to the desktop and view data from a self centered perspective. We presented a use case scenario of energy consumption on a university campus to demonstrate how our system supports cross temporal and spatial data exploration and analysis. Based on our experience and analysis, we believe that this system has great potential in assisting in the exploration and analysis of spatiotemporal data.

Title: The Quest for Omnioculars: Embedded Visualization for Augmenting Basketball Game Viewing Experiences
Description Engilish:
Sports competition data has become increasingly complex, typically including multivariate data such as player performance statistics, historical team records, and athlete position tracking information. Although many visual analysis systems have been developed for sports analysts to extract insights, there are few tools targeted at fans to improve their understanding and participation in sports data during live matches. By presenting additional data in actual game views, embedded visualization has the potential to enhance the gaming experience for fans. However, we know very little about how to design such visualizations embedded in live competitions. In this work, we propose a user centered design study to develop interactive embedded visualization aimed at improving the on-site viewing experience for basketball fans.
We first conducted a formative study to describe the analytical behavior and tasks of basketball fans during games. Based on our findings, we propose a design framework to guide embedded visualization design based on specific data seeking scenarios. Based on the design framework, we propose five novel embedded visualization designs targeting five representative scenarios determined by fans, including shooting, offense, defense, player evaluation, and team comparison. Then, we developed "Omnioculars" - an interactive basketball game viewing prototype that includes embedded visualization for analyzing game data for fans. We evaluated Omnoculars with basketball fans in a simulated basketball game. The research results indicate that our design supports personalized competition data analysis and enhances understanding and participation in competitions.

Title: User-centred design of a grid health virtual reality tabletop for energy networks
Description Engilish:
So far, the application of virtual reality (VR) in the energy field has mainly been limited to safety critical training applications.
In this article, we will introduce "Grid Health VR": a platform used to understand and query the health status of specific network departments, which can share perception and understanding of network operations with a wider community. We have provided a detailed introduction on how to implement a collaborative design process to ensure that software platforms directly address real network challenges and requirements. Grid health VR represents an important concept validation, which is how to effectively extend the application of VR in the energy field beyond current training and health/safety applications.

Title: Embodied gesture interaction for immersive maps
Description Engilish: With the popularity of head mounted displays for virtual reality and augmented reality, we can create immersive maps that bring users closer to data. Reflection is a key concept that allows users to take action on virtual objects in an immersive environment. Our job is to explore how to use expressive interaction in immersive maps. We propose four design considerations for immersive map and gesture interaction: object presence, consistent physics, human skills, and direct operation. We present an example of an immersive flow map that includes a range of novel expressive gesture interactions that align with the proposed design considerations. Sensory interaction allows users to directly manipulate immersive flow graphs and explore origin destination flow data in novel ways. Authors of immersive maps can use the four design considerations proposed to create expressive gesture interactions. The discussed interaction examples are applicable to various types of immersive maps, hoping to inspire others to invent more expressive interactions for immersive maps.

Title: From off-site to on-site: A Flexible Framework for XR Prototyping in Sports Spectating
Description Engilish: Developing and researching Extended Reality (XR) prototypes for sports observation is extremely challenging as on-site testing opportunities are limited and often cannot be used for development and debugging. In addition, conducting user research and prototype evaluation in such a large, unrestricted on-site activity environment is also a problem. Due to these limitations, we need a flexible XR prototype development framework that can be used for off-site testing, debugging, and user research, as well as directly applied on-site during sports events. We have developed a flexible XR prototype process framework with different fidelity levels. This framework combines our experience with the challenges faced by remote work to provide solutions for on-site problems. We demonstrated how to develop different XR prototypes using the proposed framework, such as micro laboratory prototypes, mixed use cases using indirect AR, off site VR prototypes, and actual on-site AR prototypes. Our method can be used for AR and XR projects with limited access to the target environment.

Title: Towards Embodied Interaction for Geospatial Energy Sector Analytics in Immersive Environments
Description Engilish: We introduce a tool for immersive analysis of space energy data. This tool is built on the basis of ImAxes, which is designed specifically for immersive analysis of abstract data in virtual environments and is extended through a geospatial layer, allowing for iteration and collaborative perception. We have developed new interactive technologies that allow users to freely choose data variables, combine them into charts, and create interactive visualizations on maps using filters and data lenses. The fusion between various independent data sources can be directly carried out in the hands of humans who need to understand and explore these data sources. In this article, we will introduce the development process of the system and demonstrate a usage scenario using data from the Australian National Energy Analysis and Research Program.

Title: Visually Communicating Microgrid Complexity
Description Engilish: Data visualization helps to support participation and understanding of complex processes; However, the visualization of microgrid energy systems is rare. In this study, we are motivated by the microgrid established by Monash University in Australia to explore the field of microgrid visualization. Taking Monash microgrid as a case study, we adopted a user centered visual design process. By interviewing different stakeholders of microgrids, we collected data and visualization requirements, and identified key visualization tasks. We have prioritized these tasks based on feasibility. We have designed and developed a digital prototype for large screen display. A formal evaluation of the prototype was conducted with stakeholders and suggestions for future work were collected. Microgrid experts believe that the proposed prototype can effectively meet their needs and has further potential in the energy field.

Title: Improving Information Sharing and Collaborative Analysis for Remote GeoSpatial Visualization Using Mixed Reality
Description Engilish: Remote collaboration systems allow users from different locations to work together to complete tasks, which is exactly what many practical applications require. For example, environmental pollution is a complex issue that requires a variety of professional knowledge to fully understand, as pollutants are not only scattered locally, but also regionally and even globally. This article introduces a remote collaboration visualization system based on mixed reality technology, which provides shared presence, information sharing, and collaborative analysis functions. We first developed an immersive visualization method that analyzes multi-attribute and geospatial data through intuitive multi model interaction, simulating the effect of co location collaboration. Then, we further designed a set of information sharing and collaborative analysis functions to support different users in sharing and collaborating to analyze their perception processes. We provide example results and usage scenarios to demonstrate that our system can effectively enable users to perform various immersive collaborative analysis tasks. Through two small-scale user studies, we focused on evaluating our information sharing design and system availability, and the evaluation results confirmed the effectiveness of comprehensive sharing between users, data, physical, and interactive spaces in improving the remote collaborative analysis experience.

Title: An application for geovisualization with virtual reality built on Unity3D
Description Engilish: With the rapid development of Geographic Information Systems (GIS), geographic information visualization tools are also emerging one after another. One of the tools is to use modeling techniques to present geographic information. Therefore, we have developed a geographic visualization application that achieves large-scale visualization of geographic information through application modeling or special effects. In addition, the application also provides various geographic visualization methods, especially for weather information and geographic reference information (such as forest coverage). Geographic information data can be downloaded in advance from cloud databases or obtained in real-time through HTTP requests. In order to enhance the immersion of the visual environment, the application adopts virtual reality (VR) technology. We use Unity3D as the platform because it has multiple features in modeling, special effects, and VR. This article will discuss each visualization method and its advantages and disadvantages.

Title: CityScope: A Data-Driven Interactive Simulation Tool for Urban Design. Use Case Volpe
Description Engilish: The MIT Urban Science Group (CS) studies the interactions between social, economic, and physical characteristics of urban areas to understand how people use and experience cities, thereby improving urban design practices and promoting consensus among stakeholders. For a long time, the participation process around urban transformation has relied on visual communication and complex negotiations to promote coordination among stakeholders such as community members, administrative agencies, and professional technicians. The Urban Science Group has proposed a new interactive and collaborative approach called "CityScope", which is a data-driven platform that can simulate the impact of interventions on urban ecosystems before detailed design and implementation. When stakeholders collectively interact with the platform and understand the impact of proposed intervention measures in real-time, consensus can be reached and goals can be optimized. In this article, we provide an overview of the basic analysis and visualization elements of the tool, as well as the methodology behind the tangible user interface, and demonstrate an alternative urban design strategy solution applied to the Volpe Site case study in Kendall Square, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Title: Analysing the effect of tangibile user interfaces on spatial memory
Description Engilish: Tangible user interfaces (TUIs) achieve effective and simple interaction with digital information by encapsulating it in physical form. Especially when combined with interactive surfaces, tangible user interfaces have been studied in various forms and application cases. By utilizing the human body's grip and manipulation abilities, they provide convenience for collaboration and learning. In this article, we will investigate the impact of TUI on spatial memory. In the study, we compared the performance of participants in recalling building locations previously placed on interactive desktops, whether using graphical user interfaces or touch based graphical user interfaces. Although 83.3% of participants reported stronger positional memory ability when using a graphical user interface in self-assessment, our results showed that participants had an average 24.5% higher memory accuracy when using a touch user interface.

Title: Envisioning the Emergency Operations Centre of the Future
Description Engilish: Emergencies, crises, and disasters occur frequently and have a significant impact on the lives of countless people. In response to these events, many organizations, including police, emergency services, and fire departments, worked together to mitigate the impact of these events. In addition, third-party organizations such as the Red Cross or utility companies often join. In order for all these groups to collaborate together, the Emergency Command Center (EOC) serves as a hub for centralized communication and planning. Although EOC plays a significant role, many existing EOCs still rely on aging technologies, and adopting new technologies may bring many potential improvements. Considering the impact of emergencies on human life and resources, as well as the scale of these emergencies, even minor improvements may bring significant benefits and cost savings. The Future Emergency Command Center (EOC-F) is an exploration of integrating various novel technologies in EOC design, aimed at making emergency response more efficient and collaborative. We have established a Multi Surface Environment (MSE) that utilizes various digital surfaces, including display walls, desktops, tablet devices, and mobile/wearable computing devices. In this multi surface EOC, we investigated intimate interaction and augmented reality as useful ways of transmitting and obtaining information. We also discussed how the information collected within EOC and social media analysis can drive wiser decisions during emergency response periods.

Title: Augmented Reality Based Bee Drift Analysis: A User Study
Description Engilish: The HoloBee we are introducing is a system that utilizes a head mounted augmented reality interface (Microsoft HoloLens) to visually analyze bee drift data. HoloBee can facilitate interactive manipulation and exploration of bee activity data on three-dimensional geographic terrain, thereby gaining a deeper understanding of bee drift behavior in their natural habitats. We conducted a user study comparing the task performance and user experience of HoloBee with traditional desktop applications. The results showed that although participants had much more experience interacting with the desktop interface, HoloBee was able to complete tasks in a similar amount of time and with high accuracy compared to the desktop interface. We have received positive feedback from some participants regarding the natural and intuitive interaction provided by HoloBee, while others prefer to use desktop applications. We will discuss the significance and limitations of these results and provide guidance for future work in this area.
