Title: Participatory Design of STEM Education AR Experiences for Heterogeneous Student Groups: Exploring Dimensions of Tangibility, Simulation, and Interaction
Description Engilish: In this article, we present the results of a multi-year participatory design process that explores STEM education AR experience spaces for students of different ages and abilities. Our participants include teachers, students (aged 5 to 14), educational technology experts, game designers, and human-computer interaction researchers. This work referred to the state education curriculum guidelines. The activity includes developing a set of design dimensions to guide our conceptualization process, iteratively designing, constructing, and evaluating six prototypes with our stakeholders, and collecting our observations on target students using AR STEM applications.

Title: Virtual and augmented reality game-based applications to civil engineering education
Description Engilish: Game scenes and virtual environments have shown beneficial results in engineering education. Various activities conducted in different fields indicate that students appreciate the integration of innovative technologies such as virtual reality or augmented reality into the learning process. This article introduces the virtual reality (VR) application developed by first-year students in the introductory course of the comprehensive master's degree in civil engineering. In addition, two experiments were conducted in a local school (K-12 grade students) to apply VR and augmented reality (AR) to civil engineering. After the test, a survey was conducted on the students and data was collected. The results and considerations will be revealed in the final section of this article.

Title: Combining Mobile, Tangible and Virtual World Platforms to Support Participatory Campus Planning
Description Engilish: Urban planning, especially campus planning, can greatly benefit from technologies that promote and utilize collaborative and participatory planning, including all affected stakeholders. Interactive surfaces (such as desktops and walls) and spaces (such as 3D environments) are examples of such technologies. Our research aims to explore and evaluate the applicability and effectiveness of such technologies in participatory campus planning. We introduce a prototype system that combines tangible surfaces and multi touch surfaces with a virtual world platform, providing a participatory planning approach for campus development projects.

Title: Designing on-site: Facilitating participatory contextual architecture with mobile phones
Description Engilish: Some movements in modern architecture emphasize the importance of matching buildings with their surrounding environment. However, practicing this kind of "situational architecture" is very challenging, and often the future residents of the building do not have enough ability to participate. This article explores the potential of using mobile phone technology to promote the participation of such customers in various parts of the construction process at construction sites. To this end, we introduced ArchiLens, a mobile system for interactive on-site 3D visualization of houses, and the results of field research conducted on 40 participants during the construction or renovation of houses. Research has shown that using this system helps to evoke people's imagination of the appearance and feel of future houses, and to imagine them in the background. This enables them to participate more closely in the on-site design process by iteratively reviewing design proposals and exploring other layouts and materials.

Title: Urp: a luminous-tangible workbench for urban planning and design
Description Engilish:
We introduce an urban planning system called Urp, which integrates functions to solve a wide range of problems in various fields into a physics based workbench environment. The I/O Bulb infrastructure on which this application is based allows physical building models placed on regular desktops to cast precise shadows at any time of the day; Reflected light projected from the surface of the glass exterior wall; Real time and visual overlap simulation of pedestrian level airflow; Wait a minute.

Then, we compared Urp with several early I/O Bulb applications to understand the luminous tangible interaction, which occurs when the interface allocates meaning and functionality between physical objects and visual information projected onto them. Finally, we briefly discussed two common issues among all such systems and used them as informal thinking tools for designing and analyzing luminescent tangible interfaces.

Title: Designing Nike’s Speed-Inspired Camp Victory
Description Engilish:
We collaborated with Skylab Architecture to design a three part experience that aims to include a sense of speed. Visitors will see a speed tunnel with end-to-end LED walls and 10 spatialized sound channels, all of which are controlled in real-time by athletes running on adjacent tracks, triggering unique light and sound modes. For people outside the stadium, this tunnel serves as a digital connection to exciting events.

Next, visitors are invited to compete with each other on self powered treadmills. As each 30 second face-to-face competition progresses, the volume of the room will begin to increase, and as participants run faster and more speed data becomes visualized, the sound will also become louder. The leaderboard summarizes all the data and provides numerical rewards to the fastest runner.

Title: Reimagining the Way Meta Greets The World
Description Engilish: Within a highly strategic narrative framework, we have designed and integrated over ten technology driven experiences to illustrate and contemplate digital behavior at both micro and macro levels. We enable visitors to interact with the brand, understand how it promotes self-expression and community building, and reflect global change. Social welfare activities like the Ice Bucket Challenge are abstracted and visualized, emphasizing that viral transmission can have beautiful, exponential impacts. Sharing emotions through touch screen, data will be added to the vertical bar screen ahead

Title: Main Street at eBay Headquarters by ESI Design
Description Engilish:
EBay has commissioned ESI Design to design a central building called Main Street, located in its Silicon Valley campus, to become the company's new storefront. "Architecture is a symbol of culture and brand," CEO Devin Wenig said at the grand opening ceremony of architecture.

Main Street welcomes employees and partners into a fashionable and media rich environment, capturing the strong pulse of eBay's business. It also provides much-needed flexible and fully equipped space for hosting meetings, conferences, and events.

In order to achieve a multi surface media experience on Main Street, ESI needs to find an engaging and interactive way to tell the story of eBay. The design team worked closely with eBay personnel to extract a concise and concise company story from the vast user and product data. The real-time generation of statistical data for eBay product transactions, combined with pre made content, highlights the impact of eBay's employee, buyer, and seller communities on the market and philanthropy.

In the main hall, a huge multi screen display supports real-time demonstrations and online live streaming; During meeting breaks, the screen will display a variety of environmental movies, mixed with trend data from eBay searches and purchases.

Title: Exploring the Data Within for Google
Description Engilish:
We have designed a "deep city" experience, which reflects the idea of using various technologies to delve into many different types of human data. This experience consists of three interactive devices: a passage, a city cave, and a sky trail.

These devices use the natural world and iconic destinations of New York as inspiration sources to artistically collect tourist input data, including their gestures, movement speed, voice commands, stay time, and content selection. Everyone contributes their own digital layer of data, which becomes a striking visual takeover, and when combined with the data of other guests, they will never be the same.

The beauty of digital content and sculptural space reminds people of fossil rock stripes, sparkling crystal caves, and underground portals to the above world - providing a stunning appearance for a vast amount of digital information.
